{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14075,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lilium superbum, commonly known as the Turk's cap lily, prefers consistently moist soil but does not tolerate waterlogged conditions. It's important to keep the soil evenly moist, especially during its active growing season in spring and summer. However, excessive watering can lead to bulb rot, so ensure the soil has proper drainage. During the dormant period in winter, reduce watering significantly but do not allow the soil to completely dry out. It's ideal to water the plant at the base to avoid excess moisture on the leaves, which can promote fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lilium superbum thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight a day for optimal growth. However, in extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from intense heat and prevent leaf scorch. They also tolerate dappled shade conditions but may not flower as prolifically. Ensuring adequate sunlight is crucial for healthy blooming, as insufficient light can lead to leggy growth and reduced or absent flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Lilium superbum is relatively minimal but important for maintaining plant health. Remove spent flowers promptly to prevent the plant from wasting energy on seed production, unless you want seeds. Once the flowering period is over, and the leaves start to turn yellow, cut the stems back to the ground. This helps the plant conserve energy for the next growing season. Also, regularly remove any dead or damaged leaves. Be cautious not to damage the bulb or the surrounding healthy foliage during pruning, as this can affect next year's growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Turk's-cap lily","description":"Lilium superbum is a species of true lily native to the eastern and central regions of North America. Common names include Turk's cap lily, turban lily, swamp lily, lily royal, or American tiger lily. The native range of the species extends from New Hampshire south to the Florida Panhandle, west to Missouri and Arkansas, and all the way north to Alberta.","family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Eastern North America"],"other_name":["Turk's-cap lily"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Leaf miners","Botrytis","Rust"],"propagation":["Bulb division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Lilium superbum"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained","Fertile"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Prune lightly to maintain the natural shape of the tree, avoiding severe cuts as this can stress the plant. In regions with very hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can prevent the dill from bolting too quickly, although it still needs ample daily sunlight for healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning dill involves occasional trimming to promote bushier growth and prevent the plant from becoming too leggy. Regularly pinch out the topmost growth when the plant reaches 12 inches in height to encourage a fuller appearance. Remove any yellowing or dead leaves to maintain plant health. Additionally, if you want to delay bolting (flowering), prune the flower heads as they start to form, though this will reduce seed production. Harvest dill leaves regularly, which also serves as a gentle pruning method that encourages more leaf growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Dill","description":"Dill (Anethum graveolens) is an annual herb in the celery family Apiaceae. The common name of this species is golden ear. Mulching can help conserve moisture but be cautious to not let the mulch touch the plant's stem, which can lead to rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant thrives best in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day to achieve optimal growth and flowering. Full sun exposure will help maintain its vibrant flower color and compact form, so choose a planting location accordingly."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salvia pachyphylla is essential to maintain its shape and encourage new growth. The best time to prune is in early spring before new growth begins, removing any dead or damaged stems. You can also trim back after blooming in late summer to encourage a second wave of flowers and to maintain a tidy appearance. It’s advisable not to cut into the woody part of the plant, as these areas do not readily regenerate. Regular deadheading of spent flowers will help prolong the blooming period and keep the plant looking fresh."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rose Sage","description":"Salvia pachyphylla (Blue sage, Mountain desert sage) is a perennial shrub native to California, Nevada, and Arizona. In California, it grows between 5,000 to 10,000 ft (1,500 to 3,000 m) elevation on dry rocky slopes, blooming from July to September. It reaches 1 to 2 ft (0.30 to 0.61 m) high, with blue-violet flowers, rarely rose, growing in dense clusters.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Gray-green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Rose Sage"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Salvia pachyphylla"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In regions with intense summer heat, consider providing some afternoon shade, particularly in the hottest parts of the year, to prevent leaf scorching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lycium pallidum should be done minimally to maintain its natural shape and to remove any dead or damaged branches. Focus on removing crossing branches or those that grow inward to improve air circulation within the plant. Regularly removing older branches at the base can help encourage new growth. It's best to water in the early morning or late afternoon to allow the foliage to dry before nightfall, reducing the risk of fungal diseases. During the dormant season in winter, the plant requires much less water, so keep the soil only slightly moist until new growth appears again in spring."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lilium martagon thrives in partial shade to full sun conditions. In hotter climates, more shade is beneficial to prevent stress. However, in cooler regions, it can handle more sun exposure. Proper exposure to sunlight is crucial for the plant's photosynthesis process, which supports blooming and growth. Ensure it gets at least 4-6 hours of sunlight daily for optimal health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lilium martagon is relatively straightforward. After the blooming period, allow the foliage and stems to remain until they naturally yellow and wither, as this helps the bulb store energy for the next season. Once the foliage is completely dead, it can be cut back to the ground. Additionally, remove spent flowers promptly to prevent seed formation, which can drain energy from the plant. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent the spreading of diseases while pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Martagon Lily","description":"Lilium martagon, the martagon lily or Turk's cap lily, is a Eurasian species of lily. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13985,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Diospyros virginiana, commonly known as the American persimmon, requires moderate watering. Once established, it can tolerate some drought, but young trees need regular watering to develop a strong root system. During the initial growth phase, aim to water the tree once a week, ensuring the soil is moist but not waterlogged. As the tree matures, you can reduce the frequency to every two weeks, particularly in the absence of rainfall. It's essential to allow the top layer of soil to dry between waterings to prevent root rot. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce watering needs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Diospyros virginiana thrives best in full sun conditions, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily to produce the most abundant and sweetest fruit. While it can tolerate partial shade, this will typically lead to reduced fruit yield and slower growth. In shade, the plant will focus more on growing taller to reach sunlight, rather than branching out and producing fruit. Planting your persimmon in an area with plenty of sunlight exposure will ensure vigorous growth and a bountiful harvest."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Diospyros virginiana is essential for maintaining a healthy structure and encouraging fruit production. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and light penetration. You should also thin the canopy to prevent overcrowding, which helps in fruit quality and size. Be careful not to over-prune, as this can stress the tree. Focus on maintaining a strong central leader and evenly spaced branches for optimal growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"American persimmon","description":"Diospyros virginiana is a persimmon species commonly called the American persimmon, common persimmon, eastern persimmon, \"simmon\", \"possumwood\", \"possum apples\", or \"sugar-plum\". It ranges from southern Connecticut/Long Island to Florida, and west to Texas, Louisiana, Oklahoma, Kansas, and Iowa. The tree grows wild but has been cultivated for its fruit and wood since prehistoric times by Native Americans.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Orange\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["American persimmon"],"pest_susceptibility":["Scale insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Diospyros virginiana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If you are cultivating it or observing it in its natural habitat, ensure that the substrate (decaying leaves, wood, or soil) is kept moist to simulate its ideal growing conditions. However, avoid overly wet environments, as this can lead to fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Clitocybe nebularis thrives in low-light conditions typically found in woodlands. It prefers shaded environments with dappled sunlight filtering through the canopy of trees. Direct sunlight can dry out the substrate and harm the delicate mycelium network beneath the ground. If you're cultivating this mushroom, simulate its natural growing conditions by providing shade and ensuring it is protected from direct sunlight, which helps maintain the necessary moisture levels in its growing medium. The diffuse light typical of forest floors is ideal for its development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As a mushroom, Clitocybe nebularis does not require pruning in the same way flowering plants or shrubs do. However, if you are cultivating or monitoring this species, removing visibly unhealthy or decaying fruiting bodies can help maintain a healthy and manageable growing environment. Always use clean equipment to avoid spreading contaminants or pathogens when handling mushrooms."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cloudy Clitocybe","description":"Clitocybe nebularis or Lepista nebularis, commonly known as the clouded agaric or cloud funnel, is an abundant gilled fungus which appears both in conifer-dominated forests and broad-leaved woodland in Europe and North America. Ensure the plant is in well-draining soil to avoid waterlogging. Always adjust the watering frequency based on your local climate conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Acourtia microcephala thrives in full sun to partial shade. However, the plant is adaptable and can tolerate partial shade, though it may produce fewer blooms under these conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Acourtia microcephala involves removing dead or dried-out stems and foliage, which will enhance both the plant's appearance and its overall health. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13193,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Isatis tinctoria, commonly known as woad, prefers well-draining soil and is quite drought-tolerant once established. Afterward, reduce the watering frequency; during dry spells, an occasional deep watering will suffice. Be cautious not to overwater, as woad does not like to sit in saturated soil. Mulching around the base can help retain moisture but ensure there's good drainage to avoid root rot. During winter, reduce watering significantly as the plant goes dormant and requires less moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Woad, or Isatis tinctoria, thrives in locations with full sun exposure, which helps it produce strong, vibrant foliage and flowering. Select a planting site that receives at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. The plant can tolerate partial shade, but this may result in less robust growth and affect flowering and seed production. In very hot climates, light afternoon shade can prevent the leaves from scorching. When grown indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window to ensure it receives adequate sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Isatis tinctoria is relatively straightforward and mainly involves removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain the overall appearance and health of the plant. In early spring, cut back any old growth from the previous year to encourage fresh, vigorous growth. Deadheading spent flowers can prevent unwanted self-seeding, as woad is known to self-seed quite freely if left uncontrolled. This will also redirect the plant's energy from seed production to root and leaf growth, ensuring a healthier plant overall. An annual trim after flowering can promote a neater habit and reduce any leggy growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"woad","description":"Isatis tinctoria, also called woad (/ˈwoʊd/), dyer's woad, or glastum, is a flowering plant in the family Brassicaceae. It is occasionally known as Asp of Jerusalem. Woad is also the name of a blue dye produced from the leaves of the plant. Woad is native to the steppe and desert zones of the Caucasus, Central Asia to Eastern Siberia and Western Asia (per Hegi) but is now also found in South-Eastern and Central Europe and western...","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Central Asia"],"other_name":["woad"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Isatis tinctoria"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's important to maintain consistent soil moisture without over-watering. Aim to water deeply and infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between watering sessions to prevent root rot. During the fruiting season, the frequency of watering may need to be increased to support fruit development. Monitor rainfall and adjust watering accordingly to ensure the tree is not water-stressed, but avoid waterlogging, especially in heavy clay soils."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Prunus cerasus thrives best in full sun conditions. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to produce an optimal yield of cherries. Full sun exposure ensures good fruit size, flavor, and overall tree health. If planted in a shaded location, the tree may experience reduced fruiting and susceptibility to fungal diseases due to inadequate drying of the foliage. Ensure the site chosen for planting provides unobstructed sunlight throughout the majority of the day, and avoid planting in overly shaded areas."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Prunus cerasus should be done in late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. Focus on removing dead, damaged, or diseased branches first. It's also important to thin out overcrowded areas to improve air circulation and sunlight penetration, which can help prevent disease and promote healthy fruiting. Prune to maintain an open center shape, allowing the tree to develop a strong framework. Regular light pruning encourages new growth and better fruit production, while heavy pruning may lead to stress and reduced yield."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Sour Cherry","description":"Prunus cerasus (sour cherry, tart cherry, or dwarf cherry) is a species of Prunus in the subgenus Cerasus (cherries), native to much of Europe and southwest Asia. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13478,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pittosporum crassifolium is a drought-tolerant plant that prefers well-draining soil. It should be watered deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. During the growing season, you can water the plant once every one to two weeks, depending on the climate. In the winter months, reduce watering significantly to prevent root rot. Always ensure excess water drains away to avoid waterlogging. If the leaves start to yellow, it may be a sign of overwatering, whereas wilting can indicate underwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pittosporum crassifolium thrives in full sun to partial shade. It prefers a location where it can receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. While it is adaptable to various light conditions, insufficient sunlight may lead to less dense foliage and fewer blooms. If grown indoors, place it near a south-facing window to ensure adequate light. Keep an eye out for any signs of sunburn or leggy growth, which could indicate the plant is not getting the right amount of light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pittosporum crassifolium helps maintain its shape and encourages healthy growth. It is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Start by removing any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to prevent spread. Thin out crowded branches to improve air circulation and sunlight penetration. You can also shape the plant to your desired size, but avoid cutting into old wood as it may not regrow. Light, regular trimming throughout the growing season can also help keep the plant tidy and promote bushier growth. Always use clean, sharp tools for pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Karo","description":"Pittosporum crassifolium, commonly called Karo, is a small tree or shrub native to New Zealand. Karo's original distribution was generally the top half of the North Island, although now it has naturalised throughout New Zealand and overseas in Norfolk Island and Hawaii. P. crassifolium occurs in lowland and coastal forests. Mature trees grow to about 5 metres (16 ft) in height. Other common names include stiffleaf cheesewood, and in Māori, kaikaro and kīhihi.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Karo"],"pest_susceptibility":["Scale insects","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pittosporum crassifolium"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13382,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Opuntia robusta, like most cacti, requires minimal watering. During its growing season, which is spring and summer, it should be watered thoroughly when the soil has completely dried out. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to ensure the soil is dry between waterings. In the dormant seasons of fall and winter, reduce watering significantly, perhaps only once every four to six weeks, to mimic their natural desert environment. Always use well-draining soil and containers to prevent excess moisture retention."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Opuntia robusta thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sun each day. This succulent cactus benefits from bright, unobstructed light, which supports healthy pad development and flowering. If growing indoors, position it near a south or west-facing window to ensure it receives sufficient sunlight. If placing it outside, an open, sunny location is ideal. However, gradually acclimate it to full sun if it was previously in a shaded area, to prevent sunburn on its pads. Remember, more sun will generally lead to a healthier, more robust cactus."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Opuntia robusta is relatively simple and primarily involves removing damaged or diseased pads. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to cut off pads that have developed rot or have been scarred. Pruning can also help manage the plant's size and shape, promoting a healthier growth pattern. Since this cactus can grow quite large, occasional pruning may be necessary to maintain its shape, especially in controlled environments like indoors or small gardens. Best time to prune is during its dormant period to encourage new, healthy growth in spring."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"nopal tapón","description":"Opuntia robusta, wheel cactus, nopal tapon, or camuesa, is a species of cactus in the Cactaceae family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12281,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salvia lyrata, commonly known as Lyreleaf sage, prefers moderate watering. It's important to let the soil dry out between waterings, as this plant is relatively drought tolerant. During the growing season, ensure the soil remains slightly moist, but reduce watering significantly during the winter months when the plant goes dormant. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so always check that the top inch of soil is dry before watering again. Good drainage is crucial for maintaining the health of Salvia lyrata, so consider a well-draining soil mix and a pot with drainage holes if growing in containers."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salvia lyrata thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to produce abundant blooms. In extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent the foliage from scorching. However, if the plant is positioned in too much shade, it may result in leggy growth and fewer flowers. Finding the right balance of sunlight is key for optimal growth and flowering of Salvia lyrata, making it a versatile choice for a range of garden conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salvia lyrata involves removing old or dead growth to encourage healthy new foliage and maintain a tidy appearance. You can deadhead spent flowers throughout the blooming season to promote further blooming and prevent self-seeding if undesired. In late winter or early spring, cut back the basal leaves to clean up any damaged or dead foliage and make way for new growth. Be careful to avoid cutting into the crown of the plant. Regular pruning not only enhances the appearance but can also improve air circulation around the plant, reducing the risk of fungal diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"lyreleaf sage","description":"Salvia lyrata (lyre-leaf sage, lyreleaf sage, wild sage, cancerweed), is a herbaceous perennial in the family Lamiaceae that is native to the United States, from Connecticut west to Missouri, and in the south from Florida west to Texas. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13574,"attracts":["Wildlife"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salix hookeriana, commonly known as Hooker's Willow, prefers consistently moist soil, reflecting its natural habitat in wetland areas. Water this willow regularly, ensuring the soil remains consistently damp but not waterlogged. During hot, dry periods and its early growth stages, increase the watering frequency to maintain adequate moisture. Avoid letting the soil dry out completely, as this willow is not drought-tolerant. The key is consistent moisture, so adjust your watering schedule based on the weather conditions and the plant's growth phase."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salix hookeriana thrives best in full sun but can tolerate partial shade. Ideal sunlight exposure includes at least six hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and health. While it can withstand some shade, too little sun can lead to sparse foliage and reduced vigor. In particularly hot climates, some afternoon shade may help prevent leaf scorch. Monitoring sun exposure ensures the willow maintains healthy leaf growth and fulfills its full ornamental potential. Plant it in an area where it can access ample sunlight during most of its growing period."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salix hookeriana is essential for maintaining health and desired shape. Conduct pruning in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and promote healthy growth. For shaping, gently trim back branches to your desired form, taking care not to cut excessively. Since willows grow rapidly, regular maintenance pruning is necessary to control size and form, especially in landscape settings. Ensure sterilization of pruning tools to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"coastal willow","description":"Salix hookeriana is a species of willow known by the common names dune willow, coastal willow, and Hooker's willow.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["coastal willow"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Salix hookeriana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist","Clay","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Post-establishment, watering can be significantly reduced, only ensuring that it receives water during prolonged dry spells. Overwatering should be avoided as this can lead to root rot. Providing ample sunlight ensures the plant's health and encourages vibrant coloring and seed head production. Partial shade can be tolerated but isn't ideal for its peak growth potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of sideoats grama is generally minimal. It benefits from an annual trim at the end of winter or early spring before new growth appears. This helps in removing the dead leaves and old growth, encouraging vigorous new growth in the upcoming season. During the growing season, trimming may be done to maintain desired shape or control its spread, though it is not usually necessary. Avoid heavy pruning during the growing season, as this can stress the plant and affect its natural growth cycle."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Sideoats Grama","description":"Bouteloua curtipendula, commonly known as sideoats grama, is a perennial, short prairie grass that is native throughout the temperate and tropical Western Hemisphere, from Canada south to Argentina.","family":null,"flower_color":"Brown","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico","Canada"],"other_name":["Sideoats Grama"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Bouteloua curtipendula"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the growing season, typically spring and summer, you may need to increase the frequency of watering, especially if the tree is young or freshly planted. In fall and winter, reduce the amount of water as the plant's growth slows down. Regular monitoring for disease or pest issues can help in maintaining the overall health of the tree."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Paraná Araucaria","description":"Araucaria angustifolia, the Paraná pine, Brazilian pine or candelabra tree (pinheiro-do-paraná, araucária or pinheiro brasileiro), is a critically endangered species in the conifer genus Araucaria. It's adaptable to different sunlight conditions but performs best and maintains its robust form when it receives ample direct sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Andropogon glomeratus involves cutting back the stems to the ground in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This helps maintain an attractive appearance and promotes healthy, vigorous growth in the coming season. Removing dead or damaged foliage throughout the growing season can also help keep the plant looking its best and prevent the spread of disease. It’s a low-maintenance plant, so minimal pruning is generally necessary besides this seasonal cutback."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bushy Bluestem","description":"Andropogon glomeratus is a species of grass known by the common names bushy bluestem and bushy beardgrass. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13782,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Phlox divaricata, commonly known as woodland phlox, prefers consistently moist soil, especially during its growing season in the spring. It's important not to let the soil dry out completely between waterings, as this plant thrives in a well-hydrated environment. However, ensure that the soil is well-drained to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. During the hotter summer months, you may need to increase the frequency of watering to keep the soil moist but not soggy. Regular watering will support healthy blooming and growth, enhancing the plant's natural beauty."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phlox divaricata thrives in partial to full shade, making it an ideal plant for woodland gardens or shaded borders. It performs best in areas that offer dappled sunlight for a few hours a day or consistent light shade throughout the day. Direct sunlight should be avoided during the hottest parts of the day as it can cause stress and reduce flowering. Ideally, morning sun with afternoon shade creates the perfect light conditions. Ensuring adequate shade will help maintain the plant's vibrant blooms and lush foliage while preventing overheating and excessive drying."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phlox divaricata is beneficial to encourage bushier growth and prolong the blooming period. It is best to prune in late spring after the flowers have faded. Cut back the stems by about one third to encourage a second flush of flowers. Deadhead spent flowers regularly to promote further blooming and prevent self-seeding. If you want to manage the size of the plant or remove any dead or damaged stems, do so in early spring as new growth emerges. Careful pruning helps maintain shape and encourages a denser, healthier plant over time."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"blue phlox","description":"Phlox divaricata, the wild blue phlox, woodland phlox, or wild sweet william, is a species of flowering plant in the family Polemoniaceae, native to forests and fields in eastern North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Eastern United States"],"other_name":["blue phlox"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mildew"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Phlox divaricata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12580,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ribes oxyacanthoides, commonly known as Canada Gooseberry, requires regular watering, especially during dry spells. The soil should be kept consistently moist but not waterlogged. It's important to ensure good drainage to prevent root rot. Water the plant deeply at the base to encourage deep root growth, typically once a week, or more frequently during hot and dry periods. In the fall, reduce watering as the plant enters dormancy. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering. Always adjust watering based on weather conditions and soil moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ribes oxyacanthoides thrives best in full sun to partial shade. For optimal fruit production, it should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. In regions with extremely hot summers, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. However, too much shade can reduce flowering and subsequent fruiting. Plant it in a location where it gets plenty of sunlight, especially in the morning, to ensure strong growth and a good yield. If necessary, prune nearby plants or trees to minimize excessive shading of this gooseberry species."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ribes oxyacanthoides should be done during the late winter or early spring when the plant is dormant. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches. Thin out the center to improve air circulation and light penetration, which helps prevent mildew and other fungal diseases. Cutting back some of the older, non-productive canes at the base will encourage the growth of new, fruit-bearing canes. Aim to maintain a balanced shape and size, allowing for easy harvesting of fruits and to keep the plant healthy and vigorous. Regular annual pruning will result in a more productive plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Canadian gooseberry","description":"Ribes oxyacanthoides is a species of flowering plant in the gooseberry family known by the common name Canadian gooseberry. Its various subspecies have common names of their own. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12188,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Marasmius rotula, unlike typical houseplants, does not require traditional watering as it is a type of mushroom. Instead, it thrives in moist environments where it can absorb moisture from the air and surroundings. Therefore, to ensure proper growth, maintain a humid environment without allowing the substrate to dry out completely. If cultivated indoors for educational or decorative purposes, misting the area occasionally can help maintain appropriate humidity levels. Be cautious not to over-saturate the growing medium, as excess water can lead to rot or unhealthy growth conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Marasmius rotula is not dependent on sunlight for growth, as it obtains energy through the decomposition of organic matter rather than photosynthesis. This fungus prefers shaded or low-light conditions similar to its natural forest floor environment. For optimal growth, keep it in a dim or indirect light setting, avoiding direct sunlight which can dry out the substrate and inhibit development. If cultivating indoors, ambient room light is generally sufficient, though conditions should remain moist and humid to mimic its natural habitat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable for Marasmius rotula as it is a basidiomycete fungus rather than a leafy plant. Instead of pruning, focus on maintaining a clean environment to encourage healthy growth. Remove any decayed or overly matured mushroom caps to prevent mold growth and allow space for new mushrooms to emerge. Ensure the substrate or growing medium remains uncontaminated. Regularly observe the health of the mushrooms and the environment, keeping the growing area clean to support optimal fungal growth cycles."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"collared parachute","description":"Marasmius rotula is a common species of agaric fungus in the family Marasmiaceae. Widespread in the Northern Hemisphere, it is commonly known variously as the pinwheel mushroom, the pinwheel marasmius, the little wheel, the collared parachute, or the horse hair fungus. The type species of the genus Marasmius, M. rotula was first described scientifically in 1772 by mycologist Giovanni Antonio Scopoli and assigned its current name in 1838 by Elias Fries.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","North America"],"other_name":["collared parachute"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Marasmius rotula"],"soil":["Decaying wood","Compost-rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13284,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lupinus shockleyi, commonly known as Shockley's lupine, is a drought-tolerant plant that thrives in dry conditions. When watering this plant, it is crucial to ensure the soil dries out completely between watering sessions. Overwatering should be avoided as this can lead to root rot, a common issue for lupines in general. During active growth periods in the spring and summer, you may water moderately, but watering needs significantly decrease during dormant periods in fall and winter. The plant benefits from deep but infrequent watering to encourage root system development."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lupinus shockleyi requires full sun exposure to thrive, meaning it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. This plant is native to arid and semi-arid regions, indicating its preference for sunny, open spaces. Full sun helps the plant maintain its dense leaf and flower growth and encourages robust blooming. If grown in partial shade, you may notice a reduction in flower production. Ensure the location allows ample direct sunlight throughout the day to support its growth, particularly in early morning or late afternoon for optimal results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lupinus shockleyi involves removing spent flower spikes to promote further blooming and to prevent self-seeding if control over seeding is desired. Pruning should be done during the growing season, typically in late spring to early summer. It's also beneficial to remove any dead, damaged, or diseased foliage to maintain the plant's health and appearance. Avoid heavy pruning as this can stress the plant. Cleaning up the plant by removing old flower stalks before winter can also help reduce fungal diseases and support next season's growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Purple Desert Lupine","description":"Lupinus shockleyi is a species of lupine known by the common name purple desert lupine. It is native to the Mojave and Sonoran Deserts, where it grows in open desert habitat. It is an annual herb growing up to 30 centimeters tall. Each palmate leaf is made up of 8 to 10 leaflets measuring 1 to 3 centimeters in length. The inflorescence is a small spiral of flowers. Each flower is about half a centimeter long...","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Purple Desert Lupine"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Lupinus shockleyi"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13479,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pittosporum tenuifolium, commonly known as kohuhu or black matipo, prefers moderate watering. It is important to keep the soil consistently moist, especially during the growing seasons in spring and summer. However, ensure that the plant is not waterlogged, as too much water can lead to root rot. During the winter months, reduce watering as the plant's water requirements decrease. Always allow the top inch of soil to dry out between watering to avoid overwatering. It is crucial to adjust the watering frequency based on your climate and the plant's location to maintain healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pittosporum tenuifolium thrives best in full sun to partial shade environments. While it can tolerate a range of light conditions, providing at least six hours of sunlight per day will encourage optimal growth and foliage development. In hotter climates, it may benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent leaf scorch, while in cooler regions, more sunlight promotes lush growth. Position your pittosporum where it can receive a balance of sunlight and protection from harsh midday sun if necessary. This plant can adapt to varying light conditions, making it a versatile addition to many gardens."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pittosporum tenuifolium is essential to maintain its desired shape and size. The best time to prune is early spring before new growth starts. Start by cutting out any dead, damaged, or diseased branches. To encourage a bushier growth, trim back the ends of branches, focusing on any that disrupt the plant's overall shape or those that grow inward or cross over each other. Remember not to remove more than one-third of the plant's total size in one pruning session. Regular pruning promotes better air circulation and light penetration, essential for its health and vitality."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Kōhūhū","description":"Pittosporum tenuifolium is a small evergreen tree, up to 10 m (33 ft), native to New Zealand, commonly known as kōhūhū and black matipo, and by other Māori names kohukohu and tawhiwhi. It is sometimes grown under the cultivar name 'Nigricans', so called because of its black stems. In horticulture it is valued for its coloured foliage (cultivated variations include purple, \"silver\" and variegated leaves), and for its tolerance of some horticulturally difficult growing conditions, including dry soils...","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Kōhūhū"],"pest_susceptibility":["Scale insects","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pittosporum tenuifolium"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13383,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Oreostemma alpigenum, commonly known as alpine aster, prefers well-drained soil and does not require frequent watering once it is established. It is tolerant of drought and excessive watering can lead to root rot. During the growing season, water the plant moderately, ensuring the soil is dry before watering again. In hot climates, you may need to water more frequently, but always ensure good drainage. Reduce watering in the fall and winter months when the plant is not actively growing, allowing the soil to dry out between watering sessions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Oreostemma alpigenum thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. It is best suited for planting in locations where it will receive the maximum amount of sun exposure, such as open fields, gardens, or containers placed in sunny areas. While it can tolerate partial shade, its flowering and growth might not be as robust as it would be under full sun conditions. Ensure the plant is not overshadowed by taller plants or structures to maximize its exposure to sunlight and promote healthy blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Oreostemma alpigenum involves removing spent flowers and dead foliage to encourage healthy growth and maintain a tidy appearance. Deadhead the plant regularly throughout the blooming season to promote continuous flowering. Cut back the flower stems to the base once the blooms fade. In late fall or early spring, prune back any dead or damaged stems to the ground to prevent disease and pest problems. This also allows room for new growth in the spring. Be careful not to over-prune, as this plant requires minimal intervention for optimal growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Tundra Aster","description":"Oreostemma alpigenum (formerly Aster alpigenus) is a perennial plant to subshrub in the Sunflower Family (Asteraceae) of the mountains of western United States, commonly known as tundra aster or Anderson's mountain crown.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Western United States","North America"],"other_name":["Tundra Aster"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Oreostemma alpigenum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12481,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Platanthera flava, commonly known as the pale green orchid, prefers moist conditions typical of wetland environments. Ensure the planting site receives adequate sunlight without being exposed to harsh, prolonged sun, which can stress the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Symphyotrichum subspicatum is beneficial to encourage bushier growth and more abundant flowering. The best time to prune is in early spring before new growth begins. Cut back old stems to about 6 inches above the ground to promote vigorous new shoots. During the blooming season, you can deadhead spent flowers to extend the blooming period and improve the plant's appearance. In late fall, after the plant has finished flowering, you can cut back the stems to ground level. Regular pruning helps maintain the plant’s shape and prevents it from becoming too leggy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Douglas' Aster","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Douglas' Aster"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Symphyotrichum subspicatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Bright, direct light can dry out the fungi and inhibit mycelial growth. Maintain high humidity levels and indirect light to support their development. Use caution with artificial lighting, ensuring it is minimal and low-intensity if necessary for visibility in the growing environment."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable for Gymnopilus junonius, as it is a mushroom. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13083,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Eulobus californicus, commonly known as California suncup, is a hardy plant that is drought-tolerant and thus prefers dry conditions. It is best to water this plant sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so it is important to ensure good drainage and avoid standing water. In hotter climates, you might need to water more frequently during prolonged dry periods, but in general, rainwater should be sufficient. Reduce watering significantly, or stop altogether, during its dormancy in the fall and winter months."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eulobus californicus thrives best in full sunlight. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight daily to maintain healthy growth and prolific flowering. While it can tolerate some light shade, particularly in hotter climates, too much shade can result in leggy plants with fewer blooms. Ideal planting locations are open areas with direct access to sunlight throughout most of the day. In extremely hot and arid regions, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent stress from excessive heat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Eulobus californicus should be done minimally as it mostly self-manages its growth. The primary goal of pruning should be to maintain its shape and remove any dead or damaged stems, particularly in the late winter or early spring before new growth starts. This plant can become leggy, so trimming back some of the stems can encourage a fuller and bushier plant. Always use clean and sharp gardening tools to avoid any infection or damage to the plant. Regular deadheading of spent flowers can prompt additional blooming."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"California primrose","description":"Eulobus californicus, is a species of flowering plant in the evening primrose family known by the common name California suncup. It is native to California, Arizona, and adjacent northwestern Mexico, where it grows in scrub, chaparral, and desert plant communities.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California","North America"],"other_name":["California primrose"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Eulobus californicus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Dry"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12581,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Amsinckia spectabilis, known as the common fiddleneck, prefers moderately dry conditions and is relatively drought-tolerant once established. It typically does not require frequent watering, and it's important to allow the soil to dry out between watering sessions to prevent root rot. During the growing season, water occasionally, making sure not to over-water. In winter, reduce watering significantly as the plant enters dormancy and demands even less moisture. In natural settings, Amsinckia often thrives without supplemental watering, relying on rainfall, especially in areas with suitable climate."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Amsinckia spectabilis thrives in full sun and requires at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily to perform well. This plant is adapted to open areas, such as fields and roadsides, and flourishes in bright light conditions. Although it can tolerate a range of light exposures, including partial shade, inadequate sunlight may result in leggy growth and fewer blooms. If growing indoors or in an area with limited direct sunlight, consider supplementing with grow lights to provide the necessary amount of light for robust growth and flowering. Adequate sunlight exposure enhances the plant's overall health and blooming capacity."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Amsinckia spectabilis is generally minimal and primarily involves trimming away dead or damaged stems and old flowers to encourage healthy growth and prevent disease. After blooming, you may choose to deadhead spent flowers to tidy up the plant’s appearance and potentially extend its blooming period. This plant doesn't require heavy pruning and tends to maintain a natural shape. However, if the plant becomes too leggy or untidy, light pruning can help maintain its form. Always use clean, sharp scissors or pruners to avoid damaging the plant. "}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"woolly breeches","description":"Amsinckia spectabilis is a species of fiddleneck known by the common names seaside fiddleneck and woolly breeches. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13480,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pittosporum tobira is a hardy shrub that prefers moderate watering. This plant should be watered deeply but infrequently, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the soil has good drainage. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, more frequent watering may be needed, especially if the plant is in full sun or a container. In contrast, during the fall and winter, reduce watering as the plant's growth slows down. Always adjust based on the plant's exposure to sunlight and indoor conditions if applicable."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pittosporum tobira thrives in full sun to partial shade. It performs best with at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can protect the plant from the scorching sun and prevent leaf scorch. If grown indoors, place it near a window with bright, indirect light. Inadequate sunlight may result in spindly growth and less vibrant foliage. Monitor the plant for signs of too much sun, like yellowing leaves, or too little sun, such as leggy growth, and adjust the plant’s location accordingly to ensure optimal health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pittosporum tobira helps maintain its shape and encourages denser foliage. Prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp tools to remove dead or damaged branches and to thin out crowded areas, allowing more light and air circulation. You can also shorten long branches to your desired size. Avoid cutting more than one-third of the plant at a time, as this can shock it. Regular, light pruning helps keep the plant's natural form and size, especially in a garden setting or when used as a hedge."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Japanese cheesewood","description":"Pittosporum tobira is a species of flowering plant in the Pittosporum family known by several common names, including Australian laurel, Japanese pittosporum, mock orange and Japanese cheesewood. It is native to Japan, China, and Korea, but it is used throughout the world as an ornamental plant in landscaping and as cut foliage.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Japan","China","Korea"],"other_name":["Japanese cheesewood"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Pittosporum tobira"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12189,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dennstaedtia punctilobula, commonly known as the Hay-Scented Fern, thrives in consistently moist soil. It is essential to ensure the plant remains hydrated, especially in dry periods or when grown under full sun exposure. Water this plant regularly, providing enough moisture to keep the soil evenly damp but not waterlogged. In natural habitats, it typically receives regular rainfall, so simulating these conditions will help maintain healthy growth. However, avoid allowing the plant to sit in standing water as this can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dennstaedtia punctilobula prefers partial to full shade but can tolerate some sun, especially in cooler climates. When grown under full sun, it may require additional water to prevent the fronds from becoming scorched or dry. In its natural woodland habitat, it typically receives filtered sunlight, so simulating similar conditions can enhance its growth and lushness. If planted in a location with intense afternoon sun, providing some protection or additional shade will help to maintain the health and vibrant green color of the fronds."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Dennstaedtia punctilobula is mostly about removing old, damaged, or dead fronds to boost new growth and maintain tidiness. It's best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This encourages the fern to produce fresh, vibrant fronds as the growing season starts. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears and cut the fronds at the base. Regular pruning not only improves the plant's appearance but also prevents potential pest issues. Additionally, it helps in managing its spread as it can become invasive in some areas."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"hay-scented fern","description":"Dennstaedtia punctilobula, the eastern hayscented fern or hay-scented fern, is a species of fern native to eastern North America, from Newfoundland west to Wisconsin and Arkansas, and south in the Appalachian Mountains to northern Alabama; it is most abundant in the east of its range, with only scattered populations in the west.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["hay-scented fern"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Rhizome division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Dennstaedtia punctilobula"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13384,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Orthilia secunda, commonly known as the one-sided wintergreen, thrives in moist environments but requires well-drained soil. It is adapted to forest floors, so aim to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Water the plant regularly during the growing season, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between watering sessions. During dormant periods or in the fall and winter, reduce the frequency of watering to prevent root rot, as the plant will need less moisture. It's important to avoid letting the plant sit in overly wet soil for prolonged periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Orthilia secunda naturally grows in forested areas and prefers partial to full shade, mimicking the dappled sunlight it would receive in a woodland environment. Avoid placing it in direct sunlight, which can scorch its delicate leaves and inhibit growth. If grown indoors, place it in a spot with indirect light or use sheer curtains to diffuse direct sun exposure. If grown outdoors, a location with filtered sunlight under the canopy of larger trees would be ideal. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13881,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Asplenium ceterach, commonly known as Rustyback Fern, prefers to be on the drier side. Water sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's important to ensure that the pot has good drainage. During its winter dormancy, water much less frequently. Check the soil moisture level by feeling it an inch below the surface; if it's dry there, it's time to water. Keep in mind that this plant is quite drought-tolerant due to its natural rocky habitat, so infrequent watering is generally best."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Asplenium ceterach thrives in partial to full shade, mimicking its natural rocky habitat where it often grows in crevices and shaded areas. While it can tolerate some direct sunlight, it's best to protect it from intense, direct afternoon sun that can scorch its leaves. A spot with filtered light or dappled shade is ideal. Indoors, place it in a location that receives bright, indirect light. Too little light can slow its growth, while too much direct sun can cause leaf burn. Aim to find a balance that offers bright, indirect light for optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Asplenium ceterach is not typically necessary as they grow relatively low to the ground and are naturally tidy. However, you can remove any dead or damaged fronds to maintain its appearance and overall health. Use sharp, sterile scissors or pruning shears to cut these fronds at the base near the soil level. Regularly inspecting the plant and removing browned or yellowed fronds can also help keep the plant free from pests and diseases. Be cautious not to over-prune as this plant grows relatively slowly."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Rustyback","description":"Asplenium ceterach (syn. Ceterach officinarum) is a fern species commonly known as Rustyback. It is characterised by a short rhizome which gives rise to several green fronds that have a pinnated lamina with trichomes on the abaxial (lower) surface, but not the adaxial (upper) one. These trichomes (hairs) are orange-brown in colour, hence the name \"rustyback\". The petiole is shorter than the corpus of the leaf.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia","Africa"],"other_name":["Rustyback"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Asplenium ceterach"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13784,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hydrophyllum virginianum, also known as Virginia Waterleaf, prefers consistently moist soil, especially during its active growing period in spring and early summer. It thrives in well-drained soil, so water it regularly to maintain even soil moisture. However, avoid letting the plant sit in water, which can lead to root rot—ensure the soil dries slightly between waterings. During hotter months, increase watering frequency as required, but reduce watering in fall and winter when the plant's growth slows down. Always monitor the plant's condition to adjust watering as necessary."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Virginia Waterleaf prefers partial to full shade environments, making it an ideal plant for forested or woodland garden areas. It can tolerate some morning sun, but exposure to intense afternoon sun should be avoided to prevent leaf scorch. Dappled sunlight filtered through tree canopies suits it well, replicating its natural habitat under deciduous trees. If grown in too much sun, it may require more frequent watering and may exhibit slower growth. It's important to ensure it receives adequate shade, especially during the hottest parts of the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hydrophyllum virginianum is minimal but necessary to keep it healthy and tidy. Remove any dead or yellowing leaves as they appear to encourage new growth and prevent disease. You can also trim back spent flower stalks after blooming in late spring or early summer to enhance its appearance and prevent self-seeding if not desired. In late fall, cut back any dead foliage to the base of the plant to prepare for winter dormancy, promoting a tidy garden bed and allowing for renewed growth in the following spring."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Virginia waterleaf","description":"The Virginia waterleaf or eastern waterleaf (Hydrophyllum virginianum, often misspelled as virginicum) is an herbaceous perennial plant native to Eastern North America. The plant sometimes spreads by rhizomes to form large colonies in wooded areas. It can also spread by seeds. The seedling usually appear early to mid-spring. Flowers are blue, white, or purple, appearing in mid to late spring. Flowers exposed to sunlight bleach rapidly. Often the newer leaves are solid green with white spots...","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Virginia waterleaf"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Hydrophyllum virginianum"],"soil":["Rich","Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure that any removed plant debris is disposed of properly to prevent further dispersal and growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Rush Skeletonweed","description":"Chondrilla juncea is a species of flowering plant in the daisy family known by a number of common names, including rush skeletonweed, gum succory, devil's grass, and nakedweed. Water the plant thoroughly and allow the top inch of the soil to dry out between waterings. It's important not to let the soil completely dry out or to become waterlogged. During its dormant period in late summer and fall, reduce watering significantly to prevent bulb rot. Proper drainage is essential, so ensure the plant is in well-draining soil and that any container has ample drainage holes."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lilium washingtonianum thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive around 6 to 8 hours of sunlight per day. In hotter climates, providing afternoon shade can help protect the plant from intense sun, which can scorch the leaves. In cooler areas, it can tolerate more direct sunlight. Planting it in a location that allows morning sun and afternoon shade optimizes its growth conditions. Additionally, ensure that the site is sheltered from strong winds, which can damage the tall stems of the lilies."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lilium washingtonianum involves cutting back the stalks after flowering. Once the flowers have begun to fade and the stem turns yellow, cut it back to the base, but leave the foliage intact as long as it is green to allow photosynthesis to continue. This process helps the bulb store energy for the next growing season. At the end of the growing season, remove any dead or decaying leaves or stems to prevent diseases. Avoid cutting green stems or leaves that are still providing energy to the bulbs."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Washington lily","description":"Lilium washingtonianum is a North American plant species in the lily family. It is also known as the Washington lily, Shasta lily, or Mt. Hood lily. It is named after Martha Washington and not the state of Washington; in fact, as the northern range of the plant is near Mount Hood in Oregon, it does not naturally occur in the state of Washington.","family":null,"flower_color":"White,Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Washington lily"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Botrytis","Gray mold"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Lilium washingtonianum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure that the water is well-oxygenated, with moderate to high water movement which helps prevent algae build-up and keeps the nutrients circulated. If possible, position the plant where it has access to direct or strong artificial light to support photosynthesis and growth. It's crucial for the lighting setup to be consistent, as insufficient light can hinder the plant's ability to grow effectively."},{"type":"pruning","description":"For Ulva lactuca, pruning is typically not necessary in the way it is for terrestrial plants. Instead, harvesting is a common practice. Regularly crop (or trim) the seaweed to prevent overgrowth, which can lead to reduced water flow and lower quality water. Harvesting helps maintain the overall health of the plant, as well as the health of any aquatic system it's part of. Trim back the outer leaves, which encourages new growth, and remove any damaged or decaying sections to prevent them from affecting the rest of the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Broadleaf Sea Lettuce","description":"Ulva lactuca, also known by the common name sea lettuce, is an edible green alga in the division Chlorophyta. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13577,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salsola australis, commonly known as Australian Saltbush, is highly drought-tolerant and prefers well-drained soil. Water sparingly, allowing the soil to completely dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other issues. In rainy seasons or humid climates, it may require even less water. Ensure good drainage in the container if potted, and observe the plant for signs of stress, adjusting the watering schedule accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salsola australis thrives in full sun to partial shade. If planting outdoors, choose a location that receives ample sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salsola australis helps maintain its shape and encourages new growth. It’s best done in late winter or early spring before the growing season begins. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to remove any dead or damaged branches. Thin out branches that overcrowd the plant to allow light and air to penetrate the interior, promoting healthier growth. If the plant is becoming too large or unruly, it can be pruned back more substantially without harming its vitality. Regular pruning will help prevent the plant from becoming woody and overgrown."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Southern Russian Thistle","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Southern Russian Thistle"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["December"],"scientific_name":["Salsola australis"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12190,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Filipendula ulmaria, commonly known as meadowsweet, prefers consistently moist soil. Water the plant regularly to keep the soil evenly moist, especially during dry spells or when the plant is grown in containers as they can dry out quicker. However, ensure good drainage as overly waterlogged soil can lead to root rot. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and reduce watering frequency. Adjust watering frequency based on weather conditions and soil type to maintain its moisture needs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Filipendula ulmaria thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive about 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily, but it can also tolerate more shaded situations, especially in hotter climates. In shadier areas, it still performs well but may produce slightly fewer flowers. Finding a balance between sun exposure and water availability will optimize the plant's growth and flowering potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Filipendula ulmaria is relatively straightforward. After the flowering period, which typically occurs in the summer, spent flower heads can be cut back to encourage a tidy appearance and potentially stimulate a second bloom or prepare the plant for dormancy. Regularly removing any dead or damaged foliage throughout the growing season can help maintain plant health and vigor. Use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease spread during pruning."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Meadowsweet","description":"Filipendula ulmaria, commonly known as meadowsweet or mead wort, is a perennial herb in the family Rosaceae that grows in damp meadows. It prefers moist, well-drained soil. During the growing season, water the plant thoroughly once per week, allowing the top few inches of soil to dry out between waterings. In drought conditions, you may need to water more frequently. However, be cautious not to overwater, as waterlogged soils can lead to root rot. During dormancy, reduce the frequency of watering as the plant needs less moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vitis girdiana thrives best in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. This plant is native to desert regions and is well-adapted to bright, sunny environments. Providing ample sunlight ensures robust vine growth and healthy fruit production. Ensure the plant is situated in a location where it receives unobstructed sunlight, as shaded conditions can hinder its growth and decrease grape yields. If growing indoors or in partially shaded areas, supplement with artificial lighting if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vitis girdiana is essential to encourage healthy growth and fruit production. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring, just before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged vines and thin out crowded areas to improve air circulation. Cut back weak or straggly branches to promote stronger growth. Focus on shaping the plant by maintaining a main framework of strong vines and removing any excess tendrils. Regular pruning helps manage the vine's size and encourages a more robust yield of grapes."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"desert wild grape","description":"Vitis girdiana is as species of wild grape known as the desert wild grape and valley grape. It is native to southern California in the United States and to Baja California in Mexico....","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Purple\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States - California"],"other_name":["desert wild grape"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Anthracnose"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Vitis girdiana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's ideal to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, while underwatering can cause the plant to wilt. Observing the plant’s response to water is crucial; if the leaves appear wilted or droopy, it may require more frequent watering, especially in the hottest months. During the plant's dormant period, reduce watering frequency, but ensure the soil doesn't dry out completely. Always consider environmental factors such as humidity and temperature to adjust the watering schedule accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Osmadenia tenella thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. Ideally, it should receive at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily to promote vigorous growth and flowering. However, in extremely hot climates, it might benefit from some afternoon shade to protect it from intense heat. If grown indoors, placing it near a south or west-facing window would provide adequate light, but occasional adjustment might be necessary to prevent leaf scorching. Use sheer curtains if the light is too intense, and rotate the pot regularly to ensure even light exposure across the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Osmadenia tenella involves removing dead or diseased parts to encourage healthy growth and maintain an attractive shape. It is best done after the flowering period to avoid cutting away potential blooms. Use sharp, clean pruning shears to make precise cuts at a 45-degree angle, which helps prevent disease entry. Aim to cut just above a node or branching point to promote new growth. Be cautious of over-pruning; this could stress the plant. Additionally, removing weak or overcrowded stems can increase airflow and light penetration, supporting overall plant health and vigor."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"False Rosinweed","description":"Osmadenia is a genus of flowering plants in the daisy family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13578,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salsola soda is a drought-tolerant plant and requires minimal watering, making it ideal for arid environments. It is best to allow the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. Generally, watering every 10-14 days should suffice, but this can vary depending on climate, pot size, and soil type. During the hotter months, slightly more frequent watering might be necessary, while in cooler conditions, less frequent watering is better. An important indication is to water the plant when the top 2 inches of soil feel dry to the touch. "},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salsola soda thrives in full sun and requires at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day to grow optimally. It prefers bright locations and can tolerate high levels of sunlight typical of coastal or desert environments. While the plant is somewhat adaptable to varying light conditions, insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced vigor. If grown indoors, placing the plant on a sunny windowsill or using supplemental grow lights can mimic its preferred conditions. However, in extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent leaf scorching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salsola soda is not particularly required, but it can be beneficial for maintaining shape and encouraging bushier growth. The best time to prune is in early spring before new growth begins. Dead or desiccated branches should be removed to promote healthy growth. If the plant becomes too leggy or overgrown, you can trim it back by up to one-third. Always use sharp, sterilized pruning tools to make clean cuts and prevent the spread of diseases. Regularly checking the plant for any damaged or dead shoots is also recommended throughout the growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"fleshy Russian thistle","description":"Salsola soda, more commonly known in English as opposite-leaved saltwort, oppositeleaf Russian thistle, or barilla plant, is a small (to 0.7 m tall), annual, succulent shrub that is native to the Mediterranean Basin.
