{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13883,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pistacia lentiscus, or mastic tree, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering once established. Water young plants regularly to help them establish, but as they grow, reduce watering. In general, water only when the topsoil is completely dry. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it’s vital to ensure good drainage and wait until the soil has dried out between waterings. During hot and dry summers, you might need to water more frequently, while in the cooler months, reduce watering significantly to mimic the plant’s natural cycle."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pistacia lentiscus thrives in full sunlight and can withstand hot, sunny conditions typical of the Mediterranean. It needs at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth. In less sunny areas or indoors, ensure it receives as much bright light as possible. If growing indoors, placing it near a south or west-facing window can provide sufficient light. Lack of adequate sunlight may result in leggy growth and reduced vigor. During extremely hot summers, a little afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent scorching of the leaves."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pistacia lentiscus is generally done to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. Prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and light penetration within the plant. Trimming can also help manage the plant's size and encourage bushier growth. Light pruning can be done regularly to keep the plant tidy, but be careful not to remove too much at once, as this can stress the plant. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to make clean cuts and reduce the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"mastic","description":"Pistacia lentiscus (also lentisk; mastic; Greek: μαστίχα mastíkha ) is a dioecious evergreen shrub or small tree of the pistacio genus growing up to 4 m (13 ft) tall which is cultivated for its aromatic resin, mainly on the Greek island of Chios.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean","Canary Islands"],"other_name":["mastic"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Pistacia lentiscus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the growing season (spring and early summer), a light watering every 2-3 weeks is typically sufficient, while in fall and winter, watering should be even less frequent. If grown in a container, consider placing it in a south-facing spot to maximize sunlight exposure. In gardens, choose an open area free from shading by taller plants or structures."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dieteria canescens is generally not necessary for the plant’s health, but can be done to shape the plant or control its size. Morning sunlight is preferable, as it provides gentle warmth and light without the intensity that might stress the plant later in the day. If grown in an area with full sun exposure, monitor the plant closely for signs of leaf burn and consider relocating or providing shade during peak sunlight hours. Adequate sunlight helps maintain vibrant blooms and healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Anemone grayi involves removing spent flowers and any dead or damaged leaves to encourage new growth and maintain the plant's appearance. After flowering, cut back the flower stems to the base. In late fall, trim back the foliage as it begins to wither, as this helps reduce the risk of disease. During the growing season, regular deadheading is beneficial to extend bloom time. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts, and avoid pruning during extremely wet or cold conditions to minimize stress on the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Gray's anemone","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Gray's anemone"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Anemone grayi"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

For those looking to control this algae, placing affected surfaces in direct sunlight may reduce its growth due to the drying and warming effects of the sun."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning or controlling the spread of Trentepohlia aurea involves physical removal and environmental management rather than traditional pruning. Rinse the area thoroughly to prevent soapy residues from affecting other plant or animal life. Regular maintenance and cleaning of surfaces, particularly in high-humidity areas, will prevent excessive growth. Monitoring and reducing conditions conducive to algae growth, like excess moisture, is also key in control."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Orange Rock Hair","description":"Trentepohlia aurea is a species of filamentous terrestrial green alga with a worldwide distribution. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13981,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lomandra longifolia is hardy and drought-tolerant, requiring minimal watering once established. During the initial planting phase, regular watering is essential to encourage root growth. Once the plant is established, it only requires occasional watering during extended dry periods. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. The plant prefers well-draining soil to prevent waterlogging. Mulching around the base of the plant can help retain soil moisture, reduce the frequency of watering, and suppress weed growth, which can compete for water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lomandra longifolia thrives best in full sun to partial shade environments. While the plant is adaptable to a range of light conditions, it achieves optimal growth with at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight each day. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent scorching of the leaves. However, too much shade may result in reduced flowering and a less dense growth habit. It's important to find a balance that allows the plant to receive ample sunlight while also being protected from the harshest parts of the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lomandra longifolia is generally straightforward, as it requires minimal maintenance. Pruning is mainly done to remove any dead or damaged leaves and to maintain the plant’s shape. You can cut back the entire plant close to the ground in late winter or early spring to encourage fresh, rejuvenated growth for the coming season. Avoid cutting into the crown of the plant. Pruning also helps in removing any old flower stalks, which improves the plant's appearance and promotes healthier growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Spiny-headed Mat-rush","description":"Lomandra longifolia, commonly known as spiny-head mat-rush, spiky-headed mat-rush or basket grass, is a perennial, rhizomatous herb found throughout eastern Australia. The leaves are 40 cm to 80 cm long, and generally have a leaf of about 8 mm to 12 mm wide. It grows in a variety of soil types and is frost, heat and drought tolerant. Labillardiere described Lomandra longifolia from a specimen collected in Tasmania.","family":null,"flower_color":"Cream","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Spiny-headed Mat-rush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Lomandra longifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14072,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Mesembryanthemum guerichianum is a succulent that requires minimal watering. It's important to allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season in spring and summer, water the plant every two weeks. In fall and winter, reduce watering significantly, as the plant is in a dormant state and requires less moisture. Ensure that the pot has good drainage to avoid water sitting at the bottom. Overwatering is one of the most common issues with succulents, so it's better to err on the side of underwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mesembryanthemum guerichianum thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to maintain its bright and healthy appearance. If grown indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window where it can receive ample light. However, if introducing the plant to a sunny spot, do it gradually to prevent sunburn. In extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade might protect it from intense light that can scorch the leaves. Without enough sunlight, these succulents may become leggy and lose their vibrant color."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Mesembryanthemum guerichianum is not typically necessary, but it can help control the plant's shape and remove any dead or damaged branches. Trim back excess growth after the blooming period by using clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears. Remove any spent flowers to encourage further blooming and healthy growth. Additionally, prune away any parts of the plant that appear to be diseased or pest-infested. This will not only improve the plant’s appearance but also prevent the spread of any potential issues to healthy parts of the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Brakslaai","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southern Africa"],"other_name":["Brakslaai"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Mesembryanthemum guerichianum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13786,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Thalictrum dioicum, commonly known as early meadow-rue, prefers consistently moist soil but does not do well in waterlogged conditions. To maintain ideal moisture levels, water the plant regularly, especially during dry spells, ensuring the soil is kept damp but not overly saturated. The key is to provide enough water to keep the roots moist without letting them sit in pooled water. Incorporating organic mulch around the base of the plant can help retain soil moisture and maintain a stable ground temperature, effectively reducing the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Thalictrum dioicum thrives in partial to full shade conditions, making it well-suited for woodland garden settings. It can tolerate some morning sun, but excessive exposure to direct sunlight, particularly during the hotter parts of the day, may lead to scorched leaves and reduced vigor. Providing dappled sunlight or positioning the plant under the canopy of trees offers optimal growth conditions. In regions with milder summers, it can tolerate some full sunlight, but it is crucial to ensure the soil remains moist and the plant is not exposed to harsh afternoon rays."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Thalictrum dioicum involves minimal maintenance. This plant typically benefits from cutting back dead or damaged stems after flowering to promote healthy growth and maintain its appearance. During late winter or early spring, remove any dead foliage that accumulated during the dormant period. If necessary, thin out crowded areas to increase air circulation around the plant. Regular deadheading of spent blooms can also encourage additional flowering and reduce self-seeding, although this species generally thrives with limited intervention."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"early meadow-rue","description":"Thalictrum dioicum, the early meadow-rue or quicksilver-weed, is a species of herbaceous plants in the family Ranunculaceae. This species has dioecious plants, with male and female flowers on separate plants blooming in early to mid spring.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Canada","United States"],"other_name":["early meadow-rue"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Thalictrum dioicum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12192,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Eggplants require consistent watering, especially during their active growing season. It is crucial to keep the soil evenly moist but not waterlogged to encourage healthy growth and fruit development. Water the plants deeply at least once a week, ensuring they receive approximately 1 to 1.5 inches of water per week. It may be necessary to water more frequently in hot and dry conditions. Mulching around the base of the plant can help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature, reducing the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eggplants thrive in warm weather and require full sun to grow optimally. Aim to provide them with at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day to promote strong growth and abundant fruiting. The plants do best in temperatures between 70 and 85°F (21 to 29°C). If growing eggplants indoors or in containers, place them in a sunny south-facing window or under grow lights to ensure they receive adequate light. Ensure the location is sheltered from wind and has rich, well-draining soil for optimal results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning eggplants can help improve air circulation, reduce disease risk, and encourage more fruitful growth. Begin by pinching out the growing tips of young plants to encourage bushier growth. As the plant matures, remove any yellow or diseased leaves. It's also beneficial to prune away any side shoots that develop in the plant's lower sections. Additionally, thinning out some flowers can direct energy to fewer, larger fruits. Regularly check for and remove any suckers that may sap energy from the primary fruit-bearing branches."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"eggplant","description":"Eggplant (Solanum melongena), or aubergine, is a species of nightshade, grown for its edible fruit. Eggplant is the common name in North America, Australia and New Zealand, but British English uses the French word aubergine. It is known in South Asia and South Africa as brinjal.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["India","China","Nepal"],"other_name":["eggplant"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Aphids","Whiteflies"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Solanum melongena"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the growing season in spring and summer, you may need to water it more frequently, especially if conditions are dry. Reduce watering in the fall and winter months since the plant's growth slows during this period. To avoid overwatering, allow the top inch of soil to dry out between watering sessions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Polemonium californicum thrives in partial to full shade environments, although it can tolerate some morning sun. Therefore, a north-facing or east-facing garden position often works well for its light requirements."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Polemonium californicum involves removing spent flowers and dead or damaged foliage to promote healthy growth and flowering. It's best to deadhead the plant regularly during its blooming season to encourage more blossoms. After the flowering period ends, you can cut back the plant to maintain its shape and encourage bushiness. However, be cautious not to prune too heavily, especially near the base, as excessive cutting can stress the plant. Late winter or early spring is an ideal time to perform more substantial pruning if necessary."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"California Jacob's ladder","description":"Polemonium californicum is a species of flowering plant in the phlox family known by the common names moving polemonium, low Jacob's-ladder, and California Jacob's ladder. It is native to the northwestern United States, where it grows in shady and moist habitat, such as mountain woodlands. It is a hairy, glandular rhizomatous perennial herb forming clumps of several decumbent to erect stems 30 to 50 centimeters in maximum height. The leaves are up to 20 centimeters long...","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Western North America"],"other_name":["California Jacob's ladder"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Polemonium californicum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13683,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Taraxacum erythrospermum, commonly known as red-seeded dandelion, is a hardy plant that does not require frequent watering. It is drought-tolerant and can survive with minimal water, making it suitable for dry environments. To care for this plant, ensure the soil is well-drained and water it only when the top inch of the soil feels dry. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so avoid letting the plant sit in waterlogged soil. During prolonged dry spells, occasional deep watering is beneficial to encourage deeper root growth, but generally, natural rainfall is sufficient."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Taraxacum erythrospermum thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. While it can tolerate partial shade, inadequate sunlight may lead to reduced flowering and leggy growth. This plant is adaptable to a wide range of light conditions but performs best in open, sunny locations. If grown indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window to ensure adequate light exposure. Ensure that outdoor plants are not overshadowed by larger plants or structures, as this can limit their access to sunlight and affect their overall health and vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Taraxacum erythrospermum is generally minimal, as it is a low-maintenance plant. Regularly deadhead (remove) spent flowers to prevent the plant from self-seeding and spreading uncontrollably. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut the flower stems close to the base. Removing dead or damaged leaves helps maintain the plant's appearance and health. Invasive growth can be controlled by cutting back the plant during its growing season. Always sterilize pruning tools before and after use to prevent the spread of disease. Pruning in early spring supports vigorous growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"red-seeded dandelion","description":"Taraxacum erythrospermum, known by the common name red-seeded dandelion, is a species of dandelion found in much of North America, but most commonly in the north.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["red-seeded dandelion"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Fungal diseases"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Taraxacum erythrospermum"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Overwatering can lead to root rot or other fungal diseases, so ensure the plant is in well-draining soil and avoid waterlogging. Observing the plant's natural habitat, it's used to minimal rain, so mimic similar conditions by letting nature cyclically provide moisture. In container settings, ensure pots have drainage holes to prevent standing water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Brassica tournefortii thrives in full sunlight. It is naturally found in sunny, open areas and should be exposed to direct sunlight for most of the day for optimal growth. At least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight is ideal. In environments where sunlight is limited, ensure the plant receives as much light as possible to prevent leggy and weak growth that can occur in lower light settings."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Brassica tournefortii is not commonly required since it's often considered a weed in invasive contexts. However, if you choose to cultivate it for specific purposes, you can trim it to maintain shape or control spread. Pruning usually involves removing dead or diseased foliage and stems to encourage healthy growth. Use clean, sharp shears to prevent disease spread, and target any foliage that looks wilted or has stopped producing flowers. Regularly deadheading can promote new growth and prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively, as it is known for rapidly spreading."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Saharan Mustard","description":"Brassica tournefortii is a species of plant known by the common names Asian mustard, pale cabbage, African mustard, and Sahara mustard, and is well known as an invasive species, especially in California.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mediterranean","North African","Southwestern Asia"],"other_name":["Saharan Mustard"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Flea beetles"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Brassica tournefortii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water this plant when the top few inches of soil are dry, typically every two to three weeks. In the winter months, reduce watering frequency to once every four to six weeks because the plant goes dormant and its water requirements decrease. Overwatering is a common issue and can lead to root rot, so ensure the pot has good drainage and never let the plant sit in water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aloe perfoliata thrives best under bright but indirect sunlight. Ideally, place it near a window that receives plenty of light, but avoid direct exposure to harsh midday sun as this can scorch the leaves. If growing indoors, a south or east-facing window often works well. Outdoors, they can tolerate full sun if acclimated properly, but part shade during the hottest parts of the day is beneficial. Move the plant gradually to sunnier spots to avoid shock. If light conditions are too low, consider supplementing with a grow light to maintain optimal health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aloe perfoliata is generally minimal and only necessary to remove dead or damaged leaves. Use sharp, sterilized scissors or a knife to cut off any brown, dry, or diseased leaves at the base. Removing these leaves helps prevent diseases and encourages healthier growth. Additionally, removing spent flower stalks can improve the plant's appearance and redirect energy to leaf and root development. Be cautious not to prune green, healthy leaves, as this can stress the plant unnecessarily. Prune as needed, although once or twice a year is usually sufficient."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Mitre Aloe","description":"Aloe perfoliata, the rubble aloe or mitre aloe, is a hardy creeping aloe, found in rocky, mountainous areas throughout the Western Cape, South Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"Orange-red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Mitre Aloe"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Aloe perfoliata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Southern exposures are ideal for these sun-loving natives. Avoid cutting into the woody part of the plant as this can damage it. Regular pruning keeps the plant healthy and can prolong its lifespan."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Cleveland Sage","description":"Salvia clevelandii, the fragrant sage, blue sage, Jim sage and Cleveland sage, is a perennial plant that is native to Southern California and northern Baja California, growing below 900 m (3,000 ft) elevation in California coastal sage and chaparral habitat. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12193,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Coprinopsis picacea, also known as Magpie Inkcap, is a type of mushroom rather than a traditional plant, so traditional watering guidelines don't apply. Instead, these mushrooms thrive in natural environments with high humidity and moisture, often found in woodlands rich in organic material. If cultivating in a garden or controlled setting, mimic these conditions by maintaining a humid environment, ensuring the substrate (such as decaying wood or compost-rich soil) is consistently moist, but not waterlogged, to prevent fungal growth issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Coprinopsis picacea typically grows in shaded environments such as forest floors. They prefer indirect sunlight, thriving in dappled or low light conditions found under tree canopies, as overexposure to direct sunlight can dry out the substrate and environment. If cultivating, ensure they receive only filtered or indirect light to replicate their natural habitat. Use a shade cloth or situate them under larger plants or structures to provide the necessary light conditions that mimic their natural woodland setting."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As a mushroom, Coprinopsis picacea does not require pruning like traditional plants. However, if you are growing them in a controlled setting, it's important to remove any decaying or fully dissolved fruiting bodies to maintain a clean and healthy environment for new growth. This helps prevent the spread of pests and diseases. Additionally, keeping the growing area tidy can encourage the appearance of new mushrooms when conditions are favorable."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Magpie Inkcap","description":"Coprinopsis picacea is a species of fungus in the family Psathyrellaceae. It is commonly called magpie inkcap fungus. . It was first described in 1785 by French mycologist Jean Baptiste François Pierre Bulliard in 1785 as Agaricus picaceus.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Magpie Inkcap"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Coprinopsis picacea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12387,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Clerodendrum trichotomum prefers consistently moist soil, especially when it's actively growing in the spring and summer. It should be watered regularly, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. However, ensure not to overwater as it may lead to root rot. During the dormant winter months, reduce watering frequency to keep the soil just lightly moist. It's crucial to maintain well-draining soil to prevent water logging, ensuring the plant's roots are healthy and thriving."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Clerodendrum trichotomum thrives in full sun to partial shade, with at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. While it can tolerate some shade, too little sunlight may result in reduced flowering and leggier growth. In hotter climates, offering some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch and stress. When grown indoors, it should be placed near a sunny window to receive adequate light, ensuring it maintains its vibrant foliage and abundant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Clerodendrum trichotomum is necessary to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. It is best to perform pruning in early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged branches and thin out overcrowded branches to improve air circulation. This plant can be cut back quite hard to the base if needed, as it will respond well with strong new growth. Regular trimming after flowering can also promote a bushier appearance and more vigorous blooming in the following season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Harlequin glorybower","description":"Clerodendrum trichotomum (harlequin glorybower, glorytree, peanut butter tree) is a species of flowering plant in the genus Clerodendrum. It is placed in the family Lamiaceae, or sometimes the Verbenaceae. It is native to China, Korea, Taiwan, Japan, and India.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Blue\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Japan","Korea"],"other_name":["Harlequin glorybower"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Clerodendrum trichotomum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13787,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sarcopoterium spinosum, commonly known as the thorny burnet, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering once established. During its initial growth phase, it should be watered moderately to help establish the roots. Once mature, it's best to let the soil dry out between watering sessions. In its natural habitat, it survives on rainfall, so mimic this by watering less frequently during cooler seasons and more during prolonged dry spells. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other issues, so ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent water logging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sarcopoterium spinosum thrives in full sun conditions, which helps it maintain its compact form and produce more flowers. Aim to provide the plant with at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun exposure is optimal for its growth. In regions with intense afternoon heat, consider providing some intermittent shade to prevent leaf scorch. If grown indoors or in less sunny climates, supplement with grow lights as necessary to ensure it receives ample light for photosynthesis and general vitality."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sarcopoterium spinosum is beneficial to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. Prune the plant in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Focus on removing any dead, damaged, or diseased branches. This will not only improve its aesthetic appearance but will also help to increase air circulation. Light shaping can be carried out throughout the growing season if necessary, but avoid heavy pruning during active growth phases as this can stress the plant. Always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Spiny Burnet","description":"Sarcopoterium is a genus of flowering plants in the rose family. The genus is synonymous to Poterium. The sole species within this genus, Sarcopoterium spinosum, is common to the southeast Mediterranean region and Middle East. It is a perennial bush with small flowers in inflorescence. Sarcopoterium spinosum flowers in February to April and its fruits mature in autumn, then fall to earth to germinate with the rain water.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean"],"other_name":["Spiny Burnet"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Sarcopoterium spinosum"],"soil":["Rocky","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13885,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Oenanthe crocata, commonly known as Hemlock Water Dropwort, thrives in very moist to wet soil conditions as it naturally grows in marshy or damp environments. It requires frequent watering, especially during dry spells, to keep the soil consistently moist. However, avoid waterlogging. If grown in a garden, consider planting it near ponds or areas with poor drainage to mimic its natural habitat. Ensure the soil never dries out completely by watering regularly, but be cautious of root rot by providing proper drainage. Adjust the frequency of watering based on seasonal changes."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Oenanthe crocata prefers a sunny location but is tolerant of partial shade as well. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to support robust growth. In its natural habitat, it is found in bright environments like open marshes, so replicating similar conditions will help the plant thrive. When grown in shadier spots, it may exhibit slower growth and reduced flowering. However, ensure it's not exposed to harsh afternoon sun, which could lead to leaf scorch, especially if the plant is not in a very damp location."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Oenanthe crocata is generally not necessary and should be done with caution due to its toxic nature. If you choose to prune, wear gloves and protective clothing. Trim back dead or damaged stems to encourage healthy growth and maintain a tidy appearance. Pruning can also be undertaken to control spread if the plant is getting too dense or to remove any competed or wilted foliage. However, excessive pruning should be avoided, as the plant naturally forms attractive, lush clumps. Always wash your hands and tools carefully after handling this plant."}],"care_level":"Extreme","common_name":"Hemlock Water-dropwort","description":"The water dropworts, Oenanthe /ɔɪˈnænθiː/, are a genus of plants in the family Apiaceae. Most of the species grow in damp ground, in marshes or in water.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Hemlock Water-dropwort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Oenanthe crocata"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water the plant regularly to keep the soil evenly moist, especially during dry spells or hot weather. It is important to avoid waterlogging, so ensure that excess water can drain away easily. It is advisable to water the plant early in the morning or in the evening to reduce evaporation losses and to prevent fungal diseases that can occur with wet foliage overnight."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ipomoea hederacea thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. This plant benefits from a sunny location where it receives ample light, which supports vigorous flowering and healthy growth. While it can tolerate partial shade, reduced sunlight may lead to fewer blooms and less vigorous growth. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to protect the plant from scorching. Nevertheless, ensuring plenty of morning sunlight is essential for optimal development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Ipomoea hederacea is generally minimal. Regular deadheading by removing the spent flowers encourages more blooms throughout the growing season and prevents unwanted self-seeding as the plant is known for its vigorous growth and can become invasive. If the plant becomes too large or unruly, it can be trimmed back to maintain the desired size and shape. Late winter or early spring is the best time to perform more substantial pruning before new growth starts."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"ivy-leaved morning-glory","description":"Ipomoea hederacea, the ivy-leaved morning glory, is a flowering plant in the bindweed family. The species is native to tropical parts of the Americas, and has more recently been introduced to North America. It now occurs there from Arizona to Florida and north to Ontario and North Dakota. Like most members of the family, it is a climbing vine with alternate leaves on twining stems. The flowers are blue to rose-purple with a white inner throat...","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["America"],"other_name":["ivy-leaved morning-glory"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Ipomoea hederacea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13289,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lycium californicum, commonly known as California boxthorn, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering once established. During the initial planting stage, water regularly to help the plant establish a deep root system. After the plant has been established, usually within the first year, watering can be reduced. Water about once every two to three weeks during the dry months, making sure the soil dries out between waterings. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot and other issues. The plant is adapted to arid climates and prefers dry to slightly moist soil conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lycium californicum thrives in full sun conditions. It needs at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day to perform best. This plant is well-suited to open, sunny areas and can tolerate high temperatures typical of its native arid landscapes. Ensure that the plant is not overshadowed by taller structures or plants as this can limit its access to sunlight, which may inhibit its growth and flowering. If grown in a garden setting, placing it in a south or west-facing location is ideal to maximize its exposure to sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lycium californicum is typically done to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. Prune during late fall or early winter when the plant is dormant. Start by removing any dead or damaged branches to prevent disease. Focus on thinning out dense areas to improve air circulation within the plant. This can help reduce the risk of fungal infections. Shape the plant as needed to control its size and encourage bushier growth. Light pruning throughout the growing season can also help maintain its shape and can encourage a more robust production of flowers and berries."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"California boxthorn","description":"Lycium californicum is a spreading shrub in the nightshade family known by the common names California boxthorn and California desert-thorn.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California","Mexico"],"other_name":["California boxthorn"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["December"],"scientific_name":["Lycium californicum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is tolerant of a variety of soil types, as long as they are well-drained. To ensure healthy growth, water the plant thoroughly once the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During the hotter months or in dry conditions, increase the frequency of watering, but be careful not to overwater, which can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Scouler's willow prefers full sun to partial shade, which means it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth. However, it can tolerate partial shade conditions, especially in hotter climates. To maintain optimal moisture levels, water the plant regularly, especially during periods of dry weather. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12287,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Venegasia carpesioides, commonly known as Canyon Sunflower, requires moderate watering. It prefers well-draining soil and should be watered consistently during the growing season, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings. Reduce frequency in the cooler months as the plant enters a more dormant state; overwatering at this time can lead to root rot. Ensure the plant is not sitting in waterlogged conditions, as this can cause damage. Consistent moisture is key, but always ensure the soil is not too wet to avoid fungal issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Venegasia carpesioides thrives in partial to full sunlight. It is well-suited for locations with morning sun and some afternoon shade, especially in hotter climates, to prevent leaf burn. Too much shade may inhibit flowering and lead to leggy growth, so ensure it receives at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. If you're cultivating this plant indoors, place it near a south or east-facing window to provide sufficient light, or utilize grow lights to supplement natural sunlight if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is essential for maintaining the shape and promoting the health of Venegasia carpesioides. After the blooming period, you should deadhead the spent flowers to encourage new growth and more blooms. Water this plant sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out completely between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure that it is watered only when the top few inches of soil feel dry to the touch. During prolonged dry spells or extreme heat, moderate watering intervals can be beneficial, but avoid excessive watering. This plant is more tolerant to under-watering than over-watering, making it relatively low maintenance in this regard."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Brickellia grandiflora thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to promote optimal growth and flowering. This plant is well suited for sunny, dry environments typical of its native habitats. While it can tolerate partial shade, especially in hot climates, full sunlight exposure encourages the most robust and vibrant bloom. If grown in shadier areas, it may experience leggy growth and reduced blooming. Therefore, choosing a location with plentiful sunlight ensures the healthiest development for this resilient plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"When pruning Brickellia grandiflora, focus on removing dead or damaged stems to encourage healthy growth. Pruning is best done in the late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This helps in maintaining a tidy appearance and promotes more vigorous blooming. Cut back the stems to a pair of healthy buds using sharp, clean pruning shears. Avoid excessive pruning as this plant prefers to maintain its natural shape. Regular deadheading of spent flowers can also enhance the blooming period and improve overall plant vitality."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"tasselflower brickellia","description":"Brickellia grandiflora, known by the common name tasselflower brickellbush, is a species of flowering plant in the daisy family.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["tasselflower brickellia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Brickellia grandiflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In winter, reduce watering significantly. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other issues, so it’s essential to ensure good drainage and avoid waterlogged conditions. Essentially, mimic its natural dry habitat by erring on the side of underwatering rather than overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salvia dorrii thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sun per day. This desert plant is highly tolerant of heat and sunlight, making it ideal for sunny locations. It can survive with slightly less light but may not bloom as prolifically. In regions with intense afternoon sun, some light afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch, though this plant generally prefers open, sunny areas that mimic its native desert environment. Providing ample sunlight ensures vigorous growth and a healthy display of its characteristic blue-violet flowers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salvia dorrii is essential to maintain its shape and encourage new growth. The best time for pruning is in early spring before new growth starts. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased wood first, then trim back about one-third of the plant to encourage bushier growth and more blooms. Light trimming of spent flowers during the blooming season can also promote reblooming. Avoid heavy pruning in the fall or winter, as this can lead to dieback. Always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts and prevent disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Dorr's Sage","description":"Salvia dorrii, the purple sage, Dorr's sage, fleshy sage, mint sage, or tobacco sage, is a herbaceous perennial in the family Lamiaceae. It is native to mountain areas in the western United States and northwestern Arizona, found mainly in the Great Basin Range habitat and southward to the Mojave Desert, growing in dry, well draining soils. Some large native populations of this species also are found in the Aquarius Plateau region of Southern Utah.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Gray-green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Western United States"],"other_name":["Dorr's Sage"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Salvia dorrii"],"soil":["Dry","Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13788,"attracts":["Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Celtis laevigata, commonly known as sugar hackberry, prefers consistent moisture, especially when young. Once established, it is relatively drought-tolerant, but it thrives with regular watering. During its first few growing seasons, water deeply once or twice a week to encourage deep root development. In hotter climates or during dry spells, increase watering frequency, but avoid waterlogging by allowing the soil to dry moderately between waterings. Mulching around the tree can help retain moisture and maintain more consistent moisture levels in the root zone."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sugar hackberry thrives in full sun to partial shade. It grows best with at least six hours of direct sunlight per day but can tolerate some shade, especially in hotter climates. It adapts well to a variety of light conditions, which makes it suitable for different landscapes. While it can survive in partial shade, optimal sunlight exposure will promote healthier growth and a more robust tree structure. Ensure that the tree has enough space away from taller competitors to receive adequate sunlight for photosynthesis and overall vitality."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Celtis laevigata during the dormant season, typically late winter before new growth begins. Focus on removing dead, diseased, or damaged branches. Also, remove any crossing branches to prevent rubbing and create a strong framework. Thin out crowded branches to improve air circulation and light penetration. Prune suckers and watersprouts from the base and along the trunk to maintain the tree’s shape and structure. Regular pruning helps to maintain its health and aesthetic form, but avoid over-pruning as it can stress the tree."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"sugar hackberry","description":"Celtis laevigata is a medium-sized tree native to North America. Common names include sugarberry, Southern hackberry, or in the southern U.S. sugar hackberry or just hackberry.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Purple\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["sugar hackberry"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf beetles","Cankerworms"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Celtis laevigata"],"soil":["Sandy","Loamy","Clay"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12586,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hedysarum coronarium, commonly known as French honeysuckle, prefers moderate watering. During the growing season in spring and summer, ensure the soil remains consistently moist but not waterlogged. Water the plant deeply whenever the top inch of soil feels dry. In the cooler months, reduce the frequency of watering as the plant requires less moisture. Be cautious of overwatering, especially in poorly draining soils, as this can lead to root rot. Always allow the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hedysarum coronarium thrives in full sun conditions for optimal growth and flowering. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. When planted in a garden, choose a spot that receives abundant natural light throughout the day. If grown indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window where it can receive ample sunlight. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient light may result in weaker stems and reduced flowering. Ensure the plant is not shaded by taller plantings or structures."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Hedysarum coronarium should be done to maintain the desired shape and encourage healthy growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged branches to improve air circulation. You can also cut back spent flowers to encourage further blooming and prevent self-seeding. If the plant becomes too leggy, a more severe prune may be done to promote bushier growth. Always use clean, sharp tools to minimize damage and the risk of infection."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"French Honeysuckle","description":"Sulla coronaria (French honeysuckle, cock's head, Italian sainfoin, sulla, or soola) is a perennial herb native to Malta, Algeria, Morocco, Tunisia, southern Italy and Spain, cultivated for animal fodder and hay, and for honey production.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean","North Africa","Iberian Peninsula"],"other_name":["French Honeysuckle"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Root-knot nematodes"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Hedysarum coronarium"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During its growing season in spring and early summer, keep the soil slightly moist but be careful not to overwater. Once the blooming period ends and the foliage begins to wither, the plant enters dormancy and reduces its water needs significantly. Allow the soil to dry out completely during the dormancy period in fall and winter, as excessive moisture during this time can lead to bulb rot. Adjust watering frequency based on rainfall and climate conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Brodiaea orcuttii thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to encourage maximum flower production during the blooming season. However, in extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent scorching and to extend the life of the blossoms. If planted under partial shade conditions, ensure that the shade is not too dense, as insufficient light can lead to weak, leggy growth and reduced flowering. Properly balancing sunlight exposure is key to healthy plant development and abundant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Brodiaea orcuttii is minimal and involves the removal of spent flowers and dried foliage. After the bloom period, allow the leaves to yellow and wilt naturally, as this process helps the plant store energy in the bulbs for the next growing season. Once the foliage is completely dry and has turned brown, it can be gently removed. Avoid cutting or pulling green foliage, as this can disrupt the plant's lifecycle. Regular removal of dead plant material will help maintain a tidy appearance and can prevent disease. No substantial pruning is required beyond this routine maintenance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Orcutt's brodiaea","description":"Brodiaea orcuttii is a species of flowering plant in the cluster-lily genus known by the common name Orcutt's brodiaea.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","California"],"other_name":["Orcutt's brodiaea"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb Division"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Brodiaea orcuttii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13390,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Packera cana, commonly known as \"Silvery Groundsel\" or \"Hoary Groundsel,\" requires moderate watering. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to let the soil dry out between waterings. Reduce watering significantly in the dormant winter months to prevent excessive moisture retention. In natural settings, this plant survives with little irrigation, reflecting its adaptability to arid conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Packera cana thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. In hot climates, some afternoon shade can protect it from intense heat. Too much shade may reduce its compact growth habit and flower production. When planted in its native habitat of prairies and open woodlands, it naturally receives ample sunlight, reflecting its preference for well-lit conditions. Ensure it is not completely shaded by taller plants or structures that could hinder its overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Packera cana is not generally a necessity, as it has a naturally neat growth habit. However, you can trim back spent flower stalks after blooming to tidy the appearance and encourage a tidy rosette of foliage. Pruning should ideally be done in late winter or early spring before new growth appears, ensuring healthy and robust springtime development."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"woolly groundsel","description":"Packera cana is a species of flowering plant in the aster family known by the common name woolly groundsel. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13789,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Glandularia canadensis, commonly known as rose verbena, requires moderate watering. It prefers well-drained soil and should be watered deeply but infrequently. Allow the top one to two inches of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. It is drought-tolerant once established, but during prolonged dry spells, especially in hotter climates, additional watering may be necessary to ensure optimal growth and blooming. Avoid overhead watering to reduce the risk of fungal diseases, and instead, focus on water at the base of the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Glandularia canadensis thrives best in full sun conditions, which means it needs at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight may result in fewer blooms and a leggier growth habit. Plant it in a sunny spot where it will receive ample light for optimal blooming. If grown indoors, place it near a south-facing window where it can get the most sunlight possible. In regions with extremely hot summers, some afternoon shade may help to prevent the plant from becoming stressed."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Glandularia canadensis is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging continuous blooms. In late winter or early spring, prune back any dead or damaged stems to promote new growth. Throughout the growing season, regularly deadhead spent blooms to encourage further flowering and prevent the plant from becoming leggy. If the plant begins to sprawl or looks untidy, trimming it back by a third in the middle of the blooming season can help rejuvenate it. Be sure to use clean, sharp tools to make cuts, reducing the risk of transmitting diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"rose vervain","description":"Glandularia canadensis, commonly called rose mock vervain, is a species of flowering plant in the verbena family (Verbenaceae). {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13486,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Platanthera dilatata, commonly known as the tall white bog orchid, prefers consistently moist or wet soil conditions, as it naturally grows in marshes, bogs, and wet meadows. To mimic its natural habitat, water the plant regularly and ensure the soil does not dry out completely. Avoid standing water to prevent root rot. Using distilled or rainwater is preferable, as this plant can be sensitive to water impurities. Maintain high humidity levels around the plant to support its growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Platanthera dilatata thrives in partial shade to full sun conditions, which closely reflects its native habitats where it receives dappled light. In a garden setting, providing morning sun with afternoon shade can be ideal, especially in hotter climates where intense midday sun can stress the plant. If placed indoors, position this orchid near an east-facing window for gentle morning light. It's important to avoid deep shade, as insufficient light can lead to leggy growth and poor flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Platanthera dilatata is minimal, as it is a herbaceous plant. Once the flowering period is over and the plant's leaves and stem begin to yellow and die back naturally, these can be carefully trimmed to prevent mold and pests. Avoid cutting green foliage as it is still photosynthesizing and feeding the plant. Deadheading spent flowers can tidy the appearance but is not necessary for plant health. During dormancy, leave the plant undisturbed to allow it to store energy for the next growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"white bog orchid","description":"Platanthera dilatata, known as tall white bog orchid, bog candle, or boreal bog orchid is a species of orchid, a flowering plant in the family Orchidaceae, native to North America. It was first formally described in 1813 by Frederick Traugott Pursh as Orchis dilatata.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["white bog orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Platanthera dilatata"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13089,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Euphorbia misera, also known as the Cliff Spurge, is a drought-tolerant plant and therefore requires minimal watering. It is important to allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season, which includes the warmer months, water the plant moderately once every two to three weeks. In its dormant period, typically in winter, reduce watering to once a month or even less. Ensure the pot or ground has excellent drainage to avoid water accumulation around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Euphorbia misera prefers a location with full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive several hours of direct sunlight each day, making it well-suited for sunny windowsills or outdoor spots that are not overly shaded. In extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent scorching. Ensure that the plant does not sit in a location with low light for extended periods, as this can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering. Aim for it to have about 6 hours of sunlight daily for optimal health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Euphorbia misera is generally not necessary, but occasional pruning can help maintain its shape and remove any dead or diseased stems. If pruning is desired to control the plant's size or encourage a bushier growth shape, do so sparingly and primarily at the start of the growing season in early spring. Use clean, sharp tools to make cuts above a node or leaf joint. Always be cautious of the plant's milky sap, which can irritate the skin and eyes. Wear gloves and eye protection when handling the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"cliff spurge","description":"Euphorbia misera, known by the common name cliff spurge, is a species of spurge in western North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Yellow\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["cliff spurge"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Euphorbia misera"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12195,"attracts":["Beetles"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Laccaria laccata, commonly known as the deceiver mushroom, typically grows in forested areas and does not require direct watering when cultivated naturally in outdoor settings. If growing in a controlled environment or for educational purposes, it’s crucial to maintain moisture in the soil by misting or gentle watering to mimic its natural habitat. Make sure the substrate remains slightly damp but never soggy, as excessively wet conditions can lead to mold and rot. It's important to simulate its natural balance, so check moisture levels regularly and adjust as necessary."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Laccaria laccata thrives in conditions similar to its natural forest floor habitat, which means it typically prefers dappled sunlight or partial shade. When attempting to cultivate Laccaria laccata, you should aim to mimic these conditions by keeping them in areas with filtered light rather than direct sunlight. Exposure to too much direct sunlight can be damaging and dry out the environment, which is not ideal for their growth. Ensuring some indirect light will help support their development and subsequent fruiting phases."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Mushrooms like Laccaria laccata don't require pruning in the traditional sense as they do not have leaves or branches. However, if you're cultivating them, you should harvest the mushrooms as they mature, before they begin to deteriorate. Use a sharp knife to cut the mushrooms at the base of the stem for clean removal. Removing mature specimens promptly encourages further growth and prevents overmaturity, which can lead to decomposition and attract pests that might harm the mycelial network."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"deceiver","description":"Laccaria laccata, commonly known as the deceiver, or waxy laccaria, is a white-spored species of small edible mushroom found throughout North America and Europe. It is a highly variable mushroom (hence “deceiver”), and can look quite washed out, colorless and drab, but when younger it often assumes red, pinkish brown, and orange tones. The species is often considered by mushroom collectors to be a “mushroom weed” because of its abundance and plain stature.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","North America","Asia"],"other_name":["deceiver"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Laccaria laccata"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13887,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vinca difformis, also known as intermediate periwinkle, prefers moderately moist soil but is quite adaptable and can tolerate some periods of drought. Water the plant thoroughly during its growing season in spring and summer. Ensure that the soil is well-draining to prevent root rot, as Vinca difformis does not like to sit in waterlogged conditions. Reduce watering during fall and winter when the plant’s growth slows. Always allow the top layer of soil to dry out between waterings. This will help maintain optimal soil moisture without overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vinca difformis thrives well in partial shade to full shade conditions. It can adapt to a variety of light conditions but prefers protected spots where the intense midday sun is filtered. In very hot and sunny areas, providing some afternoon shade can prevent the leaves from scorching and help maintain the deep green color of the foliage. This plant is ideal for growing under trees or in north-facing gardens where sunlight is limited. Though it can tolerate full sun with adequate moisture, it truly excels in shadier locations."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vinca difformis is essential to maintain its shape and prevent it from becoming too invasive, as it can spread quickly in favorable conditions. Trim back the plant after flowering, usually in late spring to summer, to encourage more bushy growth and more flowering. Regularly remove any dead or damaged stems and leaves throughout the growing season to promote good air circulation and prevent disease. If the plant becomes too leggy or overgrown, more severe pruning can be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Intermediate Periwinkle","description":"Vinca difformis, commonly called the Intermediate Periwinkle, is an evergreen, flowering subshrub native to Western Europe, including the Iberian Peninsula, France, the Italian Peninsula and Sardinia. Its whitish-blue flowers have a blooming season from late winter to early spring. It grows to about half a meter, and forms mats over a meter across.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean"],"other_name":["Intermediate Periwinkle"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Whiteflies"],"propagation":["Cutting","Layering Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Vinca difformis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's important to keep the soil evenly moist, especially during its active growing season in spring and summer. However, excessive watering can lead to bulb rot, so ensure the soil has proper drainage. During the dormant period in winter, reduce watering significantly but do not allow the soil to completely dry out. It's ideal to water the plant at the base to avoid excess moisture on the leaves, which can promote fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lilium superbum thrives in full sun to partial shade. They also tolerate dappled shade conditions but may not flower as prolifically. Remove spent flowers promptly to prevent the plant from wasting energy on seed production, unless you want seeds. Once the flowering period is over, and the leaves start to turn yellow, cut the stems back to the ground. This helps the plant conserve energy for the next growing season. Also, regularly remove any dead or damaged leaves. Be cautious not to damage the bulb or the surrounding healthy foliage during pruning, as this can affect next year's growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Turk's-cap lily","description":"Lilium superbum is a species of true lily native to the eastern and central regions of North America. Common names include Turk's cap lily, turban lily, swamp lily, lily royal, or American tiger lily. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13984,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Bulgaria inquinans, commonly known as the Black Bulgar, is a type of fungus and does not require traditional \"watering\" as plants do. However, for cultivation purposes, maintaining a moist environment is key. If you are growing them in a controlled environment, ensure the substrate they are growing on is kept consistently damp but not waterlogged. High humidity levels significantly contribute to their growth, so consider using a humidity dome or regularly misting them to maintain the required moisture levels. Always avoid standing water, as it can lead to decay or deter growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Being a fungi, Bulgaria inquinans does not require direct sunlight to thrive. In fact, it usually grows in shaded, damp environments, typically on decaying wood in forests. If cultivating, it's best to mimic these conditions by providing indirect, dappled light or placement in a naturally shaded area. Direct sunlight could dry out the environment, which is counterproductive to its natural growth requirements. If you are looking to create optimal growth conditions, ensure predominantly indirect light sources while maintaining moist and humid conditions for the best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Bulgaria inquinans in the conventional sense, as it is a fungus rather than a plant. It is adaptable to varying light levels but thrives particularly well with some protection from the harsh midday sun. Ideally, place this plant where it can receive either the morning sun followed by afternoon shade or filtered sunlight throughout the day. In regions with intense heat, providing some shade will help prevent the plant's foliage from scorching. Ensure the plant receives at least 4-6 hours of sunlight daily, adjusting as needed based on its specific growing conditions and local climate."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Bromus ciliatus, or fringed brome, involves minimal maintenance since it is a grass species. Routine cleanup includes removing dead or yellowing blades to maintain a tidy appearance and promote new growth. This can be done by mowing or cutting back the plant’s foliage to a height of about 4-6 inches in early spring before new growth starts. Periodically thinning the grass can help to prevent overcrowding, which could lead to poor air circulation and disease. Avoid severe cutting during late fall to protect the plant during winter."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Fringed Brome","description":"Bromus ciliatus is a species of brome grass known by the common name fringed brome. It is native to most of North America, including most of Canada, most of the United States except for some portions of the South, and northern Mexico. It is a plant of many habitats, including temperate coniferous forest. The specific epithet ciliatus is Latin for \"ciliate\", referring to the delicate hairs of the leaf blades.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Fringed Brome"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Bromus ciliatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12390,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tremella aurantia, a species of jelly fungus, thrives in damp conditions and prefers environments rich in moisture. It doesn't require direct watering like typical houseplants; instead, it benefits from high humidity. To maintain optimal conditions, mimic its natural habitat by ensuring the growing substrate—decaying wood—remains consistently moist. If cultivating indoors, using a humidity tent or regular misting might be necessary to keep the environment sufficiently damp. Avoid letting the substrate dry out completely, as this can hinder its growth and development."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tremella aurantia doesn't require direct sunlight, as it naturally grows in shaded, humid forest environments. Instead, this fungus thrives in low-light conditions, benefiting from indirect, diffused light. If grown outdoors or in a contained environment, ensure the setup mimics the forest floor, where light is filtered through a canopy. Too much direct sunlight can dry out the growing medium and the fungus itself, so maintaining a consistently shaded and cool environment will support its health and expansion."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not traditionally applied to fungi like Tremella aurantia in the same way as it is to plant foliage. However, routine management involves removing any old or decaying specimens from the growth area to prevent the spread of mold or pathogens. This cleaning process helps maintain a healthy environment, allowing new clusters of the fungus to thrive. Regular inspection is key to manage excess organic debris, which could otherwise interfere with Tremella aurantia's growth and health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"golden ear","description":"Tremella aurantia is a species of fungus in the family Tremellaceae. The common name of this species is golden ear. T. aurantia is similar in appearance to witch's butter, Tremella mesenterica, but has basidia which are stalked instead of sessile and parasitizes the mycelium of Stereum hirsutum instead of Peniophora.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["golden ear"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Tremella aurantia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist","Humus-rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13686,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Teesdalia nudicaulis, also known as shepherd's cress, typically requires minimal watering as it is adapted to dry and well-drained soils. Overwatering should be avoided as this can lead to root rot or other fungal diseases. Water the plant only when the topsoil feels dry to the touch. In regions with sufficient rainfall, natural precipitation may provide all the moisture needed. During prolonged dry spells, occasional deep watering may be necessary. Ensure soil has good drainage to prevent waterlogging, which is detrimental to the plant's health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Teesdalia nudicaulis thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. For optimal growth, provide it with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In regions where the sun is intense, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent the leaves from scorching. While it can tolerate partial shade, more sunlight exposure generally enhances blooming and growth. Ensure the plant is placed in an area where it receives adequate light, either outdoors in a sunny garden bed or in a pot near a bright window if grown indoors."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Teesdalia nudicaulis is generally minimal, as it is a small annual or biennial herbaceous plant. It does not require regular pruning, but you can deadhead the flowers if they begin to look untidy or if you want to prevent self-seeding. Removing spent flowers can also encourage more blooms. Pruning may also involve cutting back any damaged or diseased foliage. Always use clean, sharp tools to prune and make cuts at the base of the unwanted growth to maintain a tidy appearance and prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Shepherd's Cress","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Shepherd's Cress"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Teesdalia nudicaulis"],"soil":["Dry","Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
