{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13583,"attracts":["Bees","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salvia pachyphylla, also known as Giant Purple Sage, is drought-tolerant and prefers well-drained soil. It is crucial not to overwater this plant. During its growing season in spring and early summer, water it sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Once established, it requires minimal watering, relying mostly on natural rainfall. In overly humid climates or seasons, ensure adequate soil drainage to prevent root rot. Mulching can help conserve moisture but be cautious to not let the mulch touch the plant's stem, which can lead to rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant thrives best in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day to achieve optimal growth and flowering. Salvia pachyphylla is adapted to high desert and mountainous regions, so it can handle intense sunlight better than many other plants. However, in extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent sunscald, particularly in younger plants. Full sun exposure will help maintain its vibrant flower color and compact form, so choose a planting location accordingly."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salvia pachyphylla is essential to maintain its shape and encourage new growth. The best time to prune is in early spring before new growth begins, removing any dead or damaged stems. You can also trim back after blooming in late summer to encourage a second wave of flowers and to maintain a tidy appearance. It’s advisable not to cut into the woody part of the plant, as these areas do not readily regenerate. Regular deadheading of spent flowers will help prolong the blooming period and keep the plant looking fresh."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rose Sage","description":"Salvia pachyphylla (Blue sage, Mountain desert sage) is a perennial shrub native to California, Nevada, and Arizona. In California, it grows between 5,000 to 10,000 ft (1,500 to 3,000 m) elevation on dry rocky slopes, blooming from July to September. It reaches 1 to 2 ft (0.30 to 0.61 m) high, with blue-violet flowers, rarely rose, growing in dense clusters.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Gray-green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Rose Sage"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Salvia pachyphylla"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12588,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Viola glabella, commonly known as the stream violet, thrives with consistent moisture. It prefers to be kept in consistently damp conditions, as it is naturally found in moist woodland areas. Avoid letting the soil dry out completely between waterings, as this can stress the plant. However, ensure that the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. During hot, dry periods, you may need to water more frequently to maintain adequate soil moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Viola glabella prefers partial to full shade, mimicking its native woodland habitat. It thrives under dappled sunlight, typically under the cover of larger shrubs or trees that offer filtered light. Direct exposure to harsh sunlight, especially during peak hours, can scorch the leaves. Ideal conditions would include morning sun or late afternoon sun, while the plant is shaded during the harsh midday sun. It can handle full shade but may flower better with some access to indirect sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Viola glabella is generally minimal. Deadhead spent flowers regularly to encourage continuous blooming and to help the plant conserve energy. Cut back any dead or damaged leaves to maintain the plant's appearance and health. In late autumn, trim back any overgrown or unruly stems to tidy the plant before winter dormancy. This also reduces the risk of diseases that can affect decaying plant matter during the cold months."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"stream violet","description":"Viola glabella, the stream violet or pioneer violet, is usually found along streams or in moist woods in northeastern Asia and northwestern North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["stream violet"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Viola glabella"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If placing the plant indoors, ensure it is near a bright, south-facing window where it can receive ample sunlight. Lack of sufficient light might lead to leggy growth and sparse foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Plecostachys serpyllifolia should be done to maintain its shape and promote bushier growth. Light trimming can also be done after the flowering period to maintain a compact shape and encourage denser foliage. Avoid heavy pruning as it may stress the plant. Regular pruning helps manage size and ensures a healthy, attractive appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"petite-licorice","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["petite-licorice"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Plecostachys serpyllifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13292,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lycium pallidum, commonly known as Pale Wolfberry, is a drought-tolerant plant native to arid regions. It requires infrequent watering, making it well-suited for xeriscaping and low-maintenance gardens. Water the plant deeply but sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. During periods of prolonged drought, it may benefit from occasional supplemental watering, but take care not to over-water as this can lead to root rot. Typically, watering once a month is sufficient, especially for established plants. Always adjust watering frequency based on local rainfall and temperature conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lycium pallidum thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. It's well-adapted to hot, arid environments and performs best in areas with plenty of sunlight exposure. If planted in partial shade, the plant may exhibit reduced growth and fewer blossoms or fruit. For optimum health and productivity, place the plant in a location where it receives unobstructed light. In regions with intense summer heat, consider providing some afternoon shade, particularly in the hottest parts of the year, to prevent leaf scorching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lycium pallidum should be done minimally to maintain its natural shape and to remove any dead or damaged branches. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts, thereby reducing the risk of disease. Focus on removing crossing branches or those that grow inward to improve air circulation within the plant. Regularly removing older branches at the base can help encourage new growth. Avoid over-pruning, as this can stress the plant, particularly in its natural, arid climate conditions."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pale Wolfberry","description":"Lycium pallidum is a species of flowering plant in the nightshade family known by the common names pale wolfberry and pale desert-thorn. It is native to northern Mexico and the southwestern United States. In Mexico it can be found in Sonora, Chihuahua, Zacatecas, and San Luis Potosi. In the United States it occurs from California to Texas and as far north as Utah and Colorado.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southwestern United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Pale Wolfberry"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Lycium pallidum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14076,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lilium martagon, also known as the Turk's cap lily, prefers consistently moist soil, especially during the growing season. Water the plant regularly to maintain damp conditions but be cautious to avoid waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. It's best to water in the early morning or late afternoon to allow the foliage to dry before nightfall, reducing the risk of fungal diseases. During the dormant season in winter, the plant requires much less water, so keep the soil only slightly moist until new growth appears again in spring."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lilium martagon thrives in partial shade to full sun conditions. Preferably, it should receive morning sunlight and dappled afternoon shade to protect its delicate flowers and foliage from intense afternoon heat. In hotter climates, more shade is beneficial to prevent stress. However, in cooler regions, it can handle more sun exposure. Proper exposure to sunlight is crucial for the plant's photosynthesis process, which supports blooming and growth. Ensure it gets at least 4-6 hours of sunlight daily for optimal health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lilium martagon is relatively straightforward. After the blooming period, allow the foliage and stems to remain until they naturally yellow and wither, as this helps the bulb store energy for the next season. Once the foliage is completely dead, it can be cut back to the ground. Additionally, remove spent flowers promptly to prevent seed formation, which can drain energy from the plant. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent the spreading of diseases while pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Martagon Lily","description":"Lilium martagon, the martagon lily or Turk's cap lily, is a Eurasian species of lily. It has a widespread native region extending from Portugal east through Europe and Asia as far east as Mongolia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Martagon Lily"],"pest_susceptibility":["Lily beetle","Aphids","Fungal diseases"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Lilium martagon"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13985,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Diospyros virginiana, commonly known as the American persimmon, requires moderate watering. Once established, it can tolerate some drought, but young trees need regular watering to develop a strong root system. During the initial growth phase, aim to water the tree once a week, ensuring the soil is moist but not waterlogged. As the tree matures, you can reduce the frequency to every two weeks, particularly in the absence of rainfall. It's essential to allow the top layer of soil to dry between waterings to prevent root rot. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce watering needs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Diospyros virginiana thrives best in full sun conditions, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily to produce the most abundant and sweetest fruit. While it can tolerate partial shade, this will typically lead to reduced fruit yield and slower growth. In shade, the plant will focus more on growing taller to reach sunlight, rather than branching out and producing fruit. Planting your persimmon in an area with plenty of sunlight exposure will ensure vigorous growth and a bountiful harvest."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Diospyros virginiana is essential for maintaining a healthy structure and encouraging fruit production. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and light penetration. You should also thin the canopy to prevent overcrowding, which helps in fruit quality and size. Be careful not to over-prune, as this can stress the tree. Focus on maintaining a strong central leader and evenly spaced branches for optimal growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"American persimmon","description":"Diospyros virginiana is a persimmon species commonly called the American persimmon, common persimmon, eastern persimmon, \"simmon\", \"possumwood\", \"possum apples\", or \"sugar-plum\". The diffuse light typical of forest floors is ideal for its development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As a mushroom, Clitocybe nebularis does not require pruning in the same way flowering plants or shrubs do. Water the plant regularly to maintain moisture, but allow the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. During dormant periods, typically in summer and winter, reduce watering frequency, allowing the plant to rest and soil to remain slightly drier. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and protect roots from temperature fluctuations."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Enemion biternatum thrives in partial to full shade conditions, making it ideal for woodland gardens or shaded areas. If planted in too much shade, flowering may be reduced, so finding a balance is critical. In hotter climates, ensure it is well-shaded, while cooler climates might allow more dappled sunlight. Observing the plant's response will help adjust its location for optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Enemion biternatum is generally minimal, as it is a low-maintenance plant. Remove dead or damaged foliage in early spring to encourage healthy new growth. After the flowering period, you can deadhead spent blooms to tidy up the plant and prevent self-seeding if desired. Be careful not to remove any green, healthy foliage while pruning, as this is essential for energy production through photosynthesis. Pruning is best done with clean, sharp scissors or pruners to minimize plant stress and the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"false rue anemone","description":"Enemion biternatum (syn. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13888,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Bellis sylvestris, commonly known as the southern daisy, prefers to be watered moderately. It thrives in soil that is moist but not soggy. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, water the plant regularly to keep the soil consistently moist. In the fall and winter, reduce watering as the plant is dormant and requires less moisture. To determine when to water, check the soil's dryness about an inch below the surface; water if dry. Ensure the pot (if potted) or planting area has good drainage to prevent root rot, as this plant is sensitive to overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Bellis sylvestris thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth, it's best to position the plant where it receives at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade helps prevent excessive wilting or heat stress. If planted indoors, choose a spot near a bright window with plenty of indirect light. Monitor the plant for signs of insufficient light, such as leggy growth or sparse flowering, which indicates it might need more sun exposure. Adjust positioning as necessary to ensure the plant's sunlight needs are adequately met."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Bellis sylvestris involves removing spent blooms and any dead or damaged leaves to promote healthy growth. This process, often referred to as deadheading, encourages more flowering and helps maintain the plant's appearance. It's best to prune during the growth season when you notice faded flowers. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruners to avoid tearing the plant tissue. Regular pruning not only enhances blooming but also reduces the risk of diseases. In late fall, a light trim can be done to prepare the plant for dormancy, focusing on removing any unhealthy foliage."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"southern daisy","description":"Bellis sylvestris, or the Southern daisy, is a species of the genus Bellis. During winter, reduce watering significantly as the plant goes dormant and requires less moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Woad, or Isatis tinctoria, thrives in locations with full sun exposure, which helps it produce strong, vibrant foliage and flowering. In very hot climates, light afternoon shade can prevent the leaves from scorching. When grown indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window to ensure it receives adequate sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Isatis tinctoria is relatively straightforward and mainly involves removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain the overall appearance and health of the plant. In early spring, cut back any old growth from the previous year to encourage fresh, vigorous growth. Deadheading spent flowers can prevent unwanted self-seeding, as woad is known to self-seed quite freely if left uncontrolled. This will also redirect the plant's energy from seed production to root and leaf growth, ensuring a healthier plant overall. An annual trim after flowering can promote a neater habit and reduce any leggy growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"woad","description":"Isatis tinctoria, also called woad (/ˈwoʊd/), dyer's woad, or glastum, is a flowering plant in the family Brassicaceae. It's also important to thin out overcrowded areas to improve air circulation and sunlight penetration, which can help prevent disease and promote healthy fruiting. Prune to maintain an open center shape, allowing the tree to develop a strong framework. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems and leaves to encourage vigorous growth. Pruning helps to manage its shape and prevents the plant from becoming leggy. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13584,"attracts":["Bees","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salvia vaseyi, also known as Vasey's Sage, prefers well-draining soil and should not be overwatered. Allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season, water the plant once a week if there is no rainfall, but reduce watering significantly during the fall and winter when the plant is dormant. In dry climates, this plant is drought-tolerant and can survive with minimal watering once established, making it ideal for xeriscaping and low-water gardens."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salvia vaseyi thrives in full sun but can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates. For optimal growth and flowering, place the plant where it will receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. In regions with intense summer heat, some afternoon shade can protect the plant from scorching. However, too much shade can reduce blooming and lead to leggier growth. If growing indoors or in a poorly lit area, consider supplementing with a grow light to ensure adequate lighting conditions for healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Salvia vaseyi in early spring before the growing season begins or mid-summer after the plant finishes blooming to encourage a bushier growth and more blooms. Remove spent flowers by deadheading to promote continuous flowering. Cut back any dead or damaged stems to allow the plant to focus energy on healthy growth. Pruning can also help control the size and shape of the plant, maintaining its aesthetic appeal in the garden. Avoid excessive pruning to prevent stunting the plant's growth, and always use clean, sharp tools to avoid disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"bristle sage","description":"Salvia vaseyi, the scallopleaf sage, bristle sage or wand sage, is a perennial native to the western Colorado Desert. Flowers grow in compact clusters on 1 to 2 ft (0.30 to 0.61 m) spikes. The .5 inches (1.3 cm) flowers are white, with whitish bracts, calyx, and leaves, blooming from April to June. The specific epithet was named after botanist George Vasey or for his son, George Richard Vasey, who collected the type specimen.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["bristle sage"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Salvia vaseyi"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's important to water deeply once the top 1 to 2 inches of soil feel dry to provide sufficient moisture to the root system. During the growing season, regular watering is needed, especially in dry spells, but beware of waterlogging as it can cause root rot. In winter, when the plant is dormant, reduce the watering frequency significantly as the plant uses far less moisture. Adjust watering based on environmental conditions, like humidity and temperature, to keep the plant healthy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Angelica genuflexa thrives best in partial to full sunlight. While it can tolerate full sun, it prefers some shade during the hottest part of the day, especially in regions with intense sunlight. Ideally, it should receive morning sun with some afternoon shade to avoid leaf burn. In cooler climates, it can handle more direct sun exposure. Ensuring it gets a balance of sun and shade will promote lush, healthy growth. If planting in full shade, expect slower growth and reduced flowering, so find a spot with at least a few hours of direct sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"For Angelica genuflexa, pruning is not extensively needed, but occasional maintenance can enhance growth. Remove any dead or damaged stems throughout the growing season to promote healthy growth and airflow. Prune any spent flower stalks after blooming to encourage the plant to focus energy on root development. In late fall, cut the plant back down to the base to prepare for dormancy over winter. Regular pruning helps in preventing diseases and maintains a neat appearance. Always use sharp, clean tools to avoid any damage or disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Kneeling Angelica","description":"Angelica genuflexa is a species of angelica known as kneeling angelica.
